established by the company and the company shall be held harmless for injury or death to the city employees and the city shall indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by city employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions as required by this chapter e the superintendent of wastewater treatment and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties the city holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of but not limited to inspection observation measurement sampling repair and maintenance of any portion of the wastewater facilities lying within such easement all entry and subsequent work if any on such easement shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved f access to the propertys for the purposes so enumerated in subsections a b and c of this section shall be granted to the superintendent of wastewater treatment or his or her duly authorized representatives at all times if access is denied a special inspection warrant shall be requested    city responsibility the city shall be responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the sanitary sewer system including the providing of routine maintenance of the sewer lines and the sanitary sewer lift stations the city shall not be responsible for nor shall it be held financially liable for any property damage to private property caused by sewage backup unless it can be shown that the backup was caused by city negligence under no circumstances shall the city be held financially responsible for property damage caused by sewage backups when the sewage backup is caused by one or more or the following circumstances a acts of nature including weather conditions  b the placement of materials into the sewer system by a third party whether known or unknown which cause a blockage in the system  c explosions whether caused by nature andor man made this list shall not be considered all inclusive but rather for illustration purposes only    excavations a in making excavations in streets or highways for laying service pipe or making repairs the paving and earth removed must be deposited in a manner that will occasion the least inconvenience to the public prior to work commencing a street opening permit is required b no person shall leave any such excavation made in any street or highway open at any time without barricades or approved steel plates covering the opening at night warning lights must be maintained at such excavations c in refilling the opening after the service pipes are laid the earth must be laid in layers of not more than nine inches in depth and each layer thoroughly compacted to prevent settling this work together with the replacing of sidewalks ballast and paving must be done so as to make the street as good at least as before it was disturbed and satisfactory to the city engineer no opening of the street for tapping the pipes will be permitted when the ground is frozen  2212006  prior code  9320   tapping the mains a no person except those having authorization from the wastewater superintendent or persons in their service and approved by them will be permitted under any circumstances to tap the mains or collection pipes the kind and size of the connection materials and pipe size shall be that specified in the permit or order from such wastewater superintendent to ensure that new sewers and connections to the sewer system are properly designed and constructed b pipes should always be tapped on the side and not within six inches 15 cm of the joint or within twentyfour 24 inches 60 cm of another lateral connection all service connections to mains must comply with the state plumbing code service connections to an existing sewer main shall be made by means of a saddled wye or specially adapted tee connections to existing tees or wyes shall be made with an approved bonded rubber    installation of house laterals a all service pipes laterals on private property will be installed in accordance with state of wisconsin administration design construction installation supervision and inspection of plumbing  specifically 04 building sewers b per 045 all laterals will be inspected the building sewer andor private interceptor main sewer shall be inspected upon completion of placement of the pipe and before backfilling  and tested before or after backfilling c the cost of installing building service laterals including but not limited to the costs for materials labor connections and permit fees shall be paid by the person connecting with the sewer    extensions a the city shall extend sewer mains to a new persons in accordance with the following charges and the following conditions b when an extension main is required by the prospective user such person shall make an application for such an extension in writing to the city by filing a written application for the same with the city clerk after the filing of such an application the city shall first determine the logical location of the next manhole or manholes next the city shall determine the length and location of the extension taking into consideration the prospective demands for service the capacity of downstream facilities and the orderly development of the particular area all sewer extensions shall extend along the entire frontage of the property and shall be constructed in compliance with local and state laws ordinances and regulations c the person who requests the extension shall pay the entire cost of such extension including the manhole or manholes that are part of the extension if more than one user is involved the entire cost shall be divided among these users d after making the decision as to the length and location of the extension and prior to the time of making the charge to the persons the city shall determine the benefits to be received by any parcel that can be served by such extension before making a determination as to the benefits received the common council shall first divide the area to be served into logical building lots the common council may consider the recommendations of the landowner in determining such building lots if the landowner as a part of his or her application accompanies such application with a proposed division of such land into lots for sale or use in determining the amount to be paid by the original users if more than one user is involved the division of the charge shall be made by considering each building lot owned by one of the original applicants as a separate user the decision of the common council shall be final e when the city receives a future contribution it shall after receiving the money pay such money to the previous contributors by paying to each of the previous contributors equal amounts by counting each previous contributing lot as a separate contributor the city shall not make payments to a previous contributor if ten 10 years have expired from the date of the original contribution the money paid shall be retained by the city f it is provided that the right to contribution shall follow the land and not the contributor with the reimbursement to go to the person who is the owner of the receiving lot at the time of the reimbursement if a contributor owns more than one lot at the time of contribution he or she shall be required to designate one of the lots as the lot entitled to contribution and the owner of such a lot at the time of any contribution shall receive the reimbursements for all of the lots owned by the original contributor at the time of the original contribution such lot designation shall be filed with the city clerk and may be filed in the office of the county register of deeds the owner of such designated lot may by filing a corrective designation change the designation to another lot owned by him or her as long as such new lot is one of the lots to be served by the extension the total amount of reimbursement shall be the total payment made by him or her less the benefits conferred upon the lot or lots owned by him or her at the time of his or her contribution g in addition to the charge made as above provided to each lot each user shall pay the full cost of the lateral from the main to his or her building h sewer service will be furnished only if 1 the property to be served is located within the corporate limit of the city  2 if unincorporated territory is annexed to the city sewer service shall not be extended to property in such territory until the later of the following a the time for challenging such annexation has expired and no challenge to the annexation has been commenced  b any challenge to the annexation has been finally resolved and the annexation has been adjudged to be valid 3 if unincorporated territory is annexed to the city and the city is required to provide sewer service to property in such territory sewer service shall be terminated if the annexation is adjudged to be invalid for any reason  2212006   1998  prior code  9323   additional authority the common council may at any time establish specific connection and lateral charges for any main not covered by any other provisions in this chapter or when the city has made an extension and the city has failed to provide lateral or connection charges it is further provided that the common council may amend or alter any connection or lateral charge after its establishment under the terms of this chapter or previous ordinance or resolutions    prohibitions and limitations on sewer discharge a no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described liquids or solid wastes to any sanitary sewer or to the wastewater treatment facility 1 any stormwater surface water groundwater roof runoff subsurface drainage uncontaminated cooling water swimming pool water except diatomaceous filter drains decontaminated water unless the person has obtained the prior approval of the city for such discharge in accordance with this chapter or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers or to a natural outlet approved by the committee and other regulatory agencies industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged on approval of the committee and other regulatory agencies having jurisdiction to a storm sewer or natural outlet  2 any gasoline benzene naphtha fuel oil lubricating oil or other flammable or explosive liquid solid or gas or other substances which by themselves or by interaction with other substances may cause fire or explosion hazards or in any other way be injurious to persons property or the operation of the wastewater facilities  3 any waters or waste containing toxic or poisonous substances in sufficient quantity either singly or by interaction with other wastes which will injure or interfere with any wastewater treatment process constitute a hazard to humans or animals create a public nuisance in the receiving waters of the wastewater treatment plant or interfere with the disposal of sludge  4 any waters or wastes having a ph lower than 55 or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures equipment and personnel or the wastewater facility  5 any waters or wastes having a ph in excess of 90  6 solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the wastewater facilities such as but not limited to ashes cinders sand rocks mud straw shavings metal glass rags feathers tar plastics wood unground garbage whole blood paunch manure hair or fleshings entrails and paper dishes cups milk containers etc either whole or ground by garbage grinders b the following described substances materials waters or waste shall be limited in discharges to municipal systems to concentrations or quantities which shall not harm or damage either the sewers wastewater treatment process or equipment will not have an adverse effect on the receiving stream will not result in a violation of the citys wpdes permit will not result in additional monitoring or treatment of plant waste or will not otherwise endanger public health and safety public property or constitute a nuisance the wastewater superintendent shall set limitations lower than any limitations established in the regulations below if in the superintendents judgment such more severe limitations are necessary to meet the above objectives in forming his or her opinion as to the acceptability the superintendent will give consideration to such factors as the quantity of subject waste in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers materials of construction of the sewers the wastewater treatment process employed capacity of the wastewater treatment plant degree of treatability of the waste in the wastewater treatment plant and other pertinent factors the limitations or restrictions on materials or characteristics of waste or wastewaters discharged to the sanitary sewer which shall not be violated without approval of the superintendent are as follows 1 wastewater having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty 150 degrees fahrenheit or cause the wastewater at the treatment facility to exceed one hundred four 104 degrees fahrenheit  2 any water or wastes which may contain more than twentyfive 25 milligrams per liter of oils fat grease petroleum oil nonbiodegradable cutting oils and products of mineral oil origin  3 any garbage that has not been properly shredded garbage grinders may be connected to sanitary sewers from homes hotels institutions restaurants hospitals catering establishments or similar places where garbage originates from the preparation of food in kitchens for the purpose of consumption on the premises or when served by caterers  4 any waters or waste containing pollutants regulated by chapters nr102 nr105 and nr106 of the wisconsin administrative   5 any waters or wastes containing odorproducing substances exceeding limits which may be established by the public works committee  6 any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such halflife or concentration as may exceed limits established by the public works committee in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations  7 quantities of flow concentrations or both which constitute a slug load as defined herein  8 incompatible pollutants containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the wastewater treatment processes employed or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the wastewater treatment facility effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters  9 any water or wastes which by interaction with other water or wastes in the public sewer system release obnoxious gases form suspended solids which interfere with the collection system or create a condition deleterious to structures and treatment processes  10 waters or wastes containing grease or oil emulsifiers    special agreements no statement contained in this chapter shall be construed as prohibiting any special agreement between the city and any person whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character or decontaminated water may be admitted to the wastewater treatment facility either before or after pretreatment provided that there is no impairment of the functioning of the wastewater treatment facility by reason of the admission of such wastes and no extra costs are incurred by the city without recompense by the person provided that all rates and provisions set forth herein are complied with    permit required it is unlawful to discharge to any natural waterway within the city to the citys storm sewer system or in any other area under the jurisdiction of the city any sewage or other polluted waters without first obtaining a wisconsin pollutant discharge elimination system permit wpdes permit    normal sewage service charge a there is levied and assessed upon each lot or parcel of land with a building having a lateral available to discharge normal sewage to the public sewer system a wastewater service charge based upon rates established by the common council of the city such charges shall be assessed and collected by the water utility b if any customers obtain all or part of their water from sources other than the public water utility all or any part of which is discharged into the public sewers the customer shall be required to have a water meter or meters installed for the purpose of determining the volume of water obtained from these other sources the water meters shall be furnished by the water pollution control department all costs in connection with the water meter installation shall be at the expense of the customer the water pollution control department will charge for each meter at the rate of fifty percent 50% of the minimum water service charge set for that size meter to compensate for furnishing reading and servicing the meter this charge shall be in addition to the wastewater service charge    minimum sewer sewage charge the minimum monthly wastewater service charge shall be as set by resolution of the common council  2003   1994  prior code  9341   volume charge a in addition to the minimum charge based on meter size there shall be a charge for all flows based on water usage as determined by the water utility and set by resolution of the common council b the above volume charge shall be effective for all commercial industrial residential property and public authority serviced by the citys sewer utility with the following exception 1 residential summer sewer charge averaging method residential sewer customers shall pay the volume charge as set forth in this section for the month of september inclusive which shall be calculated based on the total water usage as determined by the water utility however during the months of may inclusive the following method for calculating the volume charge shall be used during the month of may each year the water utility shall calculate the eight month average water usage for each residential customer the eight month average shall be used on the actual water usage during the preceding eightmonth period september inclusive the calculated average for each respective residential customer shall be increased by a factor of ten percent 10% to establish the residential customers summer sewer volume charge the summer sewer volume charge shall be used to calculate each respective residential customers sewer charge during the months of may june july and august in the event that a residential customers actual monthly water usage is less than the calculated average summer sewer volume charge the customers sewer charge shall be based on the actual water usage for each respective month 2 when calculating the summer sewer volume charge as per paragraph 1 any months from september when the actual water usage is less than fifty percent 50% of the calculated average of that period that months water usage shall not be used in determining the summer sewer volume charge further whenever a minimum of four months of usable water data is not available for determining the summer volume charge the summer sewer volume charge shall be based on the citys average residential sewer usage for september plus ten percent 10%  2212006   2003   1994  prior code  9342   industrial and commercial charges for other than normal wastewater a charges for wastewater other than normal wastewater shall be based on flow bod suspended solids phosphorous and such other constituents which affect the cost of collection and treatment charges shall be made in accordance with rates established by the common council of the city as set forth in subsection c of this section b all persons discharging wastes into the public sewers are subject to a surcharge in addition to any other wastewater service charge if their wastewater has a concentration greater than normal concentrations see definition the volume of flow used for computing waste surcharges shall be the metered water consumption subject to adjustments as otherwise herein provided or the actual volume of waste as determined by an industrial waste metering installation the amount of surcharge shall reflect the cost incurred by the water pollution control department in removing bod suspended solids phosphorous and other pertinent constituents c rates of surcharge the rates of surcharge for each of the aforementioned constituents will be set by resolution of the common council d in addition to the above surcharges the water pollution control departments costs of sampling and analyzing industrial wastes shall be charged to the applicable industry e where industrial wastes are of such strength or magnitude or are delivered over such a period of time that the above surcharges do not reflect the actual cost of treatment to the water pollution control department the department reserves the right to establish a special charge for handling the waste that portion of the charge related to capital investment shall be based on the design capacity required for the particular waste in no event shall the charges be less than those charges determined by applying the above surcharge  2003   1994  prior code  9343   sewer charge adjustment a sewer use charge adjustments will be made on the basis of the amount of water metered during the same billing month for the previous year unless it can be shown that a significant change in water use has occurred if a significant change in water use has occurred the sewer use charge adjustment shall be made upon the average monthly amount of water metered during the previous twelvemonth period before the significant change occurred b sewer use charge adjustments shall not be made for water metered for construction use water metered to fill swimming pools changes in metered volumes due to a change in water meters changes in metered volumes due to negligence of the property owner or tenant or any water metered other than due to faulty plumbing c adjustments to the sewer use charge will be made at fifty percent 50% of the excess water if the excess water usage was due to faulty plumbing or vandalismcriminal damage and entered the sanitary sewers it will be assumed that the water did enter the sanitary sewer system unless the property owner can prove that in fact the water did not enter the sanitary sewer system valid receipts witness or other means of proof accepted by the wastewater treatment superintendent will be accepted as adequate d adjustments to the sewer use charge will be made for one hundred percent 100% of the excess water if it can be shown that the excess water usage was due to watering new lawn prior to start date or after ending date of the summer sewer averaging program or faulty plumbing or vandalismcriminal damage and water did not enter the sanitary sewers the burden of proof as identified above will be with the property owner e adjustments to the sewer use charge will be considered if the excess water used is at least two hundred percent 200% above the water metered during the same billing month from the previous year f only one sewer use charge adjustment per meter will be permitted for any twelvemonth period g sewer use charge adjustments will only be made to charges occurring during one monthly billing period any additional sanitary sewer expenses beyond one monthly billing period will be the total responsibility of the property owner or tenant h sewer charge adjustments will be administered by the wastewater treatment superintendent i 1 if the property owner or tenant does not agree with the decisions made by the wastewater treatment superintendent he or she may appeal the decision to the public works committee the public works committee shall review each situation to ensure that the decision rendered by the wastewater treatment superintendent is consistent within the guidelines established in this chapter the public works committee shall either uphold or amend the wastewater treatment superintendents decision based on the variables involved 2 if in the wastewater treatment superintendents opinion there exists a special situation or extraordinary circumstance that is not adequately covered in this policy he or she shall refer the matter to the public works committee with a written report and recommendation the item will be placed on the agenda of the next regularly scheduled meeting of the public works committee the public works committee shall review the item and render a decision based upon the information presented the decision of the public works committee shall be final  12152015   11162010   1996  prior code  9344   submission of basic data a within three months after passage of the ordinance codified in this chapter establishments discharging industrial wastes to a public sewer shall prepare and file with the common council a report that shall include pertinent data relating to the quantity and characteristics of the wastes discharged to the wastewater works such information shall be provided as per wisconsin administrative similarly each establishment desiring to make a new connection to public sewer for the purpose of discharging industrial wastes shall prepare a file with the city a report that shall include actual or predicted data relating to the quantity and characteristics of the waste to be discharged    extension of time when it can be demonstrated that circumstances exist which would create an unreasonable burden on the establishment to comply with the time schedule imposed by a request for extension of time may be presented for consideration of the common council    high strengthtoxic industrial discharges a 1 if any waters septage or wastes are discharged or proposed to be discharged to the public sewers which waters or wastes contain substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in subsection c of this section and which in the judgment of the wastewater superintendent may have deleterious effect upon the sewage works processes equipment or receiving waters or which otherwise create a hazard to life health or constitute a public nuisance the wastewater superintendent may a reject the wastes  andor b require pretreatment to an acceptable limit for discharge to the public sewers  andor c require control over the quantities and rates of discharge  andor d require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges under the provisions of this chapter 2 the discharger may appeal the superintendents decision to the public works committee at an open meeting all applications for appeal shall be submitted within fifteen 15 calendar days of the superintendents decision the decision rendered by the public works committee shall be final and binding b the toxic pollutants subject to prohibition or regulation under this chapter shall include but need not be limited to the list of toxic pollutants or combination of pollutants established by a of the clean water act of 1977 and subsequent amendments and any list of toxic pollutants promulgated by the wisconsin department of natural resources under wisconsin statutes  wisconsin administrative   and any subsequent amendments or replacements effluent standards or prohibitions for discharge to the sanitary sewer shall also conform to the requirements of a  wisconsin statutes  and associated regulations c pretreatment standards for those pollutants which are determined not to be susceptible to treatment by the treatment works or which would interfere with the operation of such works shall conform to the requirements and associated regulations of b of the clean water act of 1977 and subsequent amendments the primary source for such regulations shall be 40 cfr 403 general pretreatment regulations for existing and new sources of pollution    control manholes a each user discharging industrial wastes into a public sewer shall construct and maintain one or more control manholes or access points to facilitate observation measurement and sampling of his or her wastes including domestic sewage b control manholes or access facilities shall be located and built in a manner acceptable to the superintendent of wastewater treatment if measuring devices are to be permanently installed they shall be of a type acceptable to the superintendent of wastewater treatment c control manholes access facilities and related equipment shall be installed by the establishment discharging the waste at its expense and shall be maintained by it so as to be in safe condition accessible and in proper operating condition at all times plans for installation of the control manholes or access facilities and related equipment shall be approved by the superintendent of wastewater treatment prior to the beginning of construction  2000  prior code  9353   measurement of flow the volume of flow used for computing the sewer service for nonseptage disposal shall be based upon the water consumption of the person as shown in the records of meter readings maintained by the utility    provisions for deductionsexemption meters a in the event that a commercial industrial or public authority unit discharging wastes into the public sewers produces evidence satisfactory to the superintendent of wastewater treatment that significant amounts of the total annual volume of water used for all purposes does not reach the sanitary sewer the commercial industrial or public authority unit may be permitted to have an exemption water meters installed residential units covered by the residential summer sewer averaging program shall not be permitted to have an exemption meter nor shall they be permitted to have a second water meter installed in their residence for the purpose of measuring water used outdoors 1 exemption meters will be charged a monthly service fee at the rate of fifty percent 50% of the wastewater service charge for that size meter to compensate for furnishing reading bill preparation and periodic calibration of meters this charge shall be in addition to the wastewater service charge b the superintendent of wastewater treatment or his or her designee shall determine the type of meter to be installed and shall inspect the location requested for such meters all costs associated with the inspection installation including any piping revision required to insure that only water not reaching the sanitary sewer is metered by the exemption meter shall be at the owners expenses the city does reserve the right to periodically inspect and calibrate the exemption meter to insure conformity of use and accuracy of meters all water meters shall be purchased from sun prairie utilities c the amount of exemption water meter shall be subtracted from the total amount of water used by the person to determine the applicable wastewater service charge  12202011   2003  prior code  9355   metering of waste devices for measuring the volume of waste discharged may be required by the wastewater superintendent if this volume cannot otherwise be determined from the metered water consumption records metering devices for determining the volume of waste shall be installed owned and maintained by the discharger a maintenance schedule must be accepted by the wastewater superintendent following approval and installation such meters may not be removed without the consent of the wastewater superintendent    waste sampling a 1 industrial wastes and septage discharged into the public sewers shall be subject to periodic inspection and analysis of character and concentration of such wastes the initial inspection and analysis of bod total suspended solids phosphorus and ammonia nitrogen shall be made by the water pollution control department at no cost to the discharger the frequency of inspection and analysis of such wastes shall be determined by the wastewater superintendent additional tests so required by the superintendent to determine compliance with this chapter shall be performed by a certified laboratory such laboratory shall be designated by the wastewater superintendent all costs associated with the additional testing shall be at the expense of the industry or licensed disposer 2 the water pollution control department shall sample for a period not to exceed two months to determine compliance with of this title which regulates the discharge of high strength and toxic wastes 3 extensions for the purpose of sampling beyond the twomonth period may be requested by the discharger the request shall be submitted in writing to the wastewater treatment plant superintendent within fifteen 15 days of the completion of the initial two month sampling period the superintendent shall have the authority to grant or deny the extension extensions may be granted for a period not to exceed two months the analysis of the wastewater shall be performed by a certified laboratory and shall be acceptable to the wastewater superintendent all costs associated with the collection and analysis shall be at the expense of the discharger 4 industries who continue to exceed the definition of normal strength waste shall be subjected to a surcharge as enumerated in the industry shall be notified in writing by the wastewater superintendent and will be given three months to install the necessary equipment for the industrial sampling program b sampling shall be conducted in such a manner as to be representative of the composition of the wastes the sampling may be accomplished either manually or by the use of mechanical equipment acceptable to the superintendent of wastewater treatment c installation operation and maintenance of the sampling facilities shall be the responsibility of the establishment discharging the waste or septage and shall be subject to the approval of the superintendent of wastewater treatment access to sampling locations for the purposes of observation inspection and sampling shall be granted to the superintendent of wastewater treatment or his or her duly authorized representatives at all times samples shall be collected and preserved as per the latest edition of standard methods for the examination of water and wastewater published by the american public health association and wisconsin administrative  2212006  prior code  9357   analyses a all measurements tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of standard methods for the examination of water and wastewater published by the american public health association and wisconsin administrative methods location times durations and frequencies are to be determined on an individual basis subject to approval by the superintendent of wastewater treatment b determination of the character and concentration of the industrial wastes and septage shall be made as required by the water pollution control department or by a certified laboratory so designated by the wastewater superintendent the analysis made by the water pollution control department shall be binding as a basis for charges if the person discharging the wastes contests the determination the wastewater superintendent may elect to have an independent certified laboratory determine the character and concentration of the waste such independent laboratory shall be acceptable to both the wastewater superintendent and the person discharging the waste all costs incurred by the water pollution control department or independent laboratory in making the determination shall be assumed by the discharger    pretreatment where required in the opinion of the superintendent of wastewater treatment to modify or eliminate wastes that are harmful to the structures processes or operation of the wastewater treatment works the person shall provide at his or her expense such preliminary treatment or processing facilities as may be determined required to render his or her wastes acceptable for admission to the public sewers if a person discharging the waste contests the determination the superintendent of wastewater treatment may elect to have an independent laboratory determine the character and concentration of the waste such independent laboratory shall be acceptable to both the superintendent of wastewater treatment and the person discharging the waste all costs incurred by the independent laboratory in making the determination shall be assumed by the discharger    submission of information plans specifications any other pertinent information relating to proposed flow equalizations pretreatment or processing facilities shall be submitted for review of the superintendent of wastewater treatment prior to the start of their construction if the effluent from such facilities is to be discharged into the public sewers the superintendent of wastewater treatment may require a user of sewer services to provide information needed to determine compliance with this chapter these requirements may include a wastewater discharge peak rate and volume over a specified time period  b chemical analyses of wastewaters  c information on raw materials processes and products affecting wastewater volume and quality  d quantity and disposition of specific liquid sludge oil solvent or other materials important to sewer use control  e a plot plan of sewers for the users property showing sewer and pretreatment facility location  f details of wastewater pretreatment facilities  of materials  g details of systems to prevent and control the losses of materials to the municipal sewer    grease andor sand interceptors grease oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when in the opinion of the building inspector they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing floatable grease or other substances specified in or any flammable wastes sand or other harmful ingredients  except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units all interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the building inspector and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection in the maintaining of these interceptors the discharger shall be responsible for the proper removal and disposal by appropriate means of the captured material and shall maintain records of the dates and means of disposal which are subject to review by the building inspector any removal and hauling of the collected materials not performed by the dischargers personnel must be performed by currently licensed disposal firms    city approval required for discharge of decontaminated water no one shall discharge decontaminated water into the citys sanitary sewer system or storm sewer system without first obtaining the approval of the city in accordance with this chapter the city shall have sole discretion over whether any approved discharge shall be discharged into the citys sanitary system or storm sewer system    application any person who wishes to obtain the citys approval to discharge decontaminated water into the citys sanitary sewer system or storm sewer system must first submit an application in writing to the city together with an application fee of two hundred dollars $20000 for review and approval in accordance with this chapter the application shall be in such form as is prescribed for that purpose and shall include the following information a the name of the person who wishes to discharge decontaminated water  b the location from which the decontaminated water is to be discharged  c the anticipated date of commencement of the discharge and the expected duration of the discharge  d the estimated volume of the discharge  e a copy of all analytical testing data or other information establishing the content of the discharge  f for all proposed discharges that the city determines shall be discharged into its storm sewer system a copy of the wpdes application any supporting materials submitted by the applicant to the wisconsin department of natural resources to obtain a wpdes permit and a copy of the wpdes permit draft permit or other correspondence between the applicant and the dnr demonstrating the status of the applicants efforts to obtain a wpdes permit  g a copy of any treatment plan approved or required by the dnr in connection with the issuance or future issuance of the applied for wpdes permit or otherwise required in connection with the proposed discharge  h any other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the city    city approval no discharge of decontaminated water to the citys sanitary sewer system or storm sewer system shall receive final approval from the city unless all of the following requirements have been satisfied a in the case of a proposed discharge to the citys storm sewer system the applicant has received a wpdes permit from the wisconsin department of natural resources approving the discharge  b the city has determined that the discharge of decontaminated water will not pose a significant risk to public health or safety city property or result in the city being exposed to liability from any third party as a result of such discharge  c the applicant has agreed to abide by all conditions imposed by the city in connection with the approval of the discharge of the decontaminated water and all other conditions set forth in this chapter  d the applicant has provided the city proof of liability insurance acceptable to the city insuring the city against liability arising from the proposed discharge of decontaminated water in lieu of such liability insurance the city in its discretion may accept a letter of credit or other security acceptable to the city for the purpose of holding the city harmless against such liability    inspection every approved discharger of decontaminated water to the citys public sewer system shall permit the citys superintendent of wastewater treatment or his or her duly authorized agent at all reasonable hours of the day to enter their premises or building to examine the pipes fixtures and other facilities that pertain to the discharge of decontaminated water and to take such samples tests or other measurements as they deem necessary each approved discharger of decontaminated water must at all times fully and honestly answer any questions put to them relative to the use and operation of their facilities for the treatment and discharge of decontaminated water    metering devices for measuring volume of decontaminated water discharged may be required by the superintendent of wastewater treatment if this volume cannot otherwise be determined metering devices for determining the volume of decontaminated water discharged into the citys public sewer system shall be installed owned and maintained by the discharger following installation such meters may not be removed without the consent of the superintendent of wastewater treatment    sampling decontaminated water discharged into the citys public sewers shall be subject to periodic inspection and analysis of character and concentration of any hazardous substances that may be contained in such decontaminated water the frequency of inspection and analysis of such discharged decontaminated water shall be determined by the superintendent of wastewater treatment any tests required by the superintendent of wastewater treatment to determine compliance with this chapter shall be performed by a certified laboratory acceptable to the superintendent of wastewater treatment all costs associated with any testing required by the city shall be at the expense of the discharger of the decontaminated water installation operation and maintenance of any required sampling facilities shall be the responsibility of the discharger of the decontaminated water and shall be subject to the approval of the superintendent of wastewater treatment access to sampling locations shall be granted to the superintendent of wastewater treatment or the citys duly authorized representative at all times samples shall be collected and preserved in accordance with the analytical test methods and procedures set forth in wis adm any amendments or replacements thereof    costs and expenses all costs and expenses incident to the discharge of the decontaminated water shall be borne by the person discharging such water the person discharging such water shall reimburse the city for any and all costs and expenses incurred by the city incident to any such discharge including but not limited to any consultants fees incurred by the city plus one and five tenths 15 times the hourly rate for city staff time devoted in any way to the discharge or application for discharge of such water the person discharging such water shall reimburse the city in full within thirty 30 days of receipt of an invoice from the city    violations whenever any of the terms and conditions of this chapter or of any permit issued by the city pertaining to the discharge of decontaminated water by any person shall have been violated the city may undertake any of the following measures a immediately take steps to prohibit the continued discharge of contaminated water by the person or facility in violation including without limitation disconnecting any connections to the citys public sewer system for such purpose  or b seek injunctive relief to immediately prohibit the discharge of such decontaminated water  or c take any other measures provided under this chapter  or d take any other enforcement measures or seek any other relief available at law or in equity    payment and penalty the sewerage service charge shall be for the corresponding period of the water bills and shall be payable to the city not later than twenty 20 days after each period a penalty of three percent of the net billing shall be added to all bills not paid by the date fixed for final payment    charges a lien all sewage charges shall be a lien upon the property service pursuant to 7 wisconsin statutes and shall be collected in the manner therein provided    disposition of revenue the amounts received from the collection of charges authorized by this chapter shall be credited to a sanitary sewerage account which shall show all receipts and expenditures of the sewerage system charges collected for replacement expenses shall be credited to a segregated nonlapsing replacement account these funds are to be used exclusively for replacement when appropriated by the city the credits to the sanitary sewerage account shall be available for the payment of the requirements for operation maintenance repairs and depreciation of the sewerage consistent with 40 cfr  any surplus outside the preview of 40 cfr  in such account shall be available for the payment of principal and interest of bonds issued and outstanding or which may be issued to provide funds for such sewerage system or part thereof and all or a part of the expenses for additions and improvements and other necessary disbursement or indebtedness and the common council may resolve to pledge each surplus or any part thereof for any such purpose all present outstanding sewer system general obligation bonds including the refunding bonds shall be paid from this fund as to both principal and interest    additional charges additional charges shall be imposed upon each lot parcel of land building or premises served by public sewer and wastewater facilities located outside the boundaries of the city to equalize local capital costs such additional charges shall result in a minimum charge for each user according to the schedule for debt repayment from utility revenues such additional charges shall be added to the sewer bill for each billing period    industrial waste pretreatment in the event the department provides pretreatment of industrial wastes the entire cost of such pretreatment shall be charged to the person producing the industrial wastes the costs shall include but not be limited to capital expenditures operation and maintenance expenses labor chemicals heat and power    remedies from failure to pay service charges a each wastewater service charge levied by or pursuant to this chapter is made a lien upon the corresponding lot land or premises served by a connection to the sanitary sewer system of the city and if the same is not paid within the period allotted for such payment such charge shall constitute a lien on the property served and be inserted in the city tax roll as provided in 7 of the wisconsin statutes in the same manner as water rates are taxed and collected under the provisions of 1 or 6607 11e of the wisconsin statutes as same has been and from time to time may be amended or recreated so far as applicable b the wastewater service charges taxed or levied pursuant to this chapter shall be collected by the water utility at 125 west main street the sewer department shall make and enforce such bylaws and regulations as may be deemed necessary for the safe economical and efficient operation management and protection of the city sewer system the wastewater treatment plant and the sewer department  2000 prior code  9375   biannual audit an audit of the departments financial standing shall be made biannually this audit will be used to review the adequacy of the then existing rates and such rates shall be adjusted if necessary to provide sufficient revenues to adequately finance the departments operation in accordance with the original intent of the rate structure the biannual audit and review shall also be used to insure that each recipient of sewage service or user class is charged in proportion to the cost of providing such recipient or user class with sewage service    damages no unauthorized person shall maliciously wilfully or negligently break damage destroy uncover deface or tamper with any structure or appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the sewerage system any person violating this provision shall upon conviction be subject to the general penalty provision of    written notice of violation any person connected to the sewerage system found to be violating a provision of this chapter shall be served by the city with a written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time for the satisfactory correction thereof the offender shall within a period of time stated in such notice permanently cease all violations    accidental discharge a the accidental discharge of any prohibited waste into any sewer shall be reported to the wastewater superintendent by the person responsible for the discharge or by the owner or occupant of the premises where the discharge occurs immediately upon obtaining knowledge of the fact of such discharge so that steps may be taken to minimize its effect on the treatment plant within fortyeight 48 hours of the discharge the person responsible shall file a written report on a form as provided by the wastewater superintendent b any person found to be responsible for accidentally allowing a deleterious discharge into the sewer system which causes damage to the treatment facility andor receiving body of water shall in addition to a forfeiture pay the amount to cover damages both values to be established by the common council    continued violations any person partnership or corporation or any officer agent or employee thereof who shall continue any violation beyond the aforesaid notice time limit provided shall upon conviction thereof be subject to the general penalty of this code of ordinances found in together with the costs of prosecution in default of payment of such forfeiture and costs such violator shall be imprisoned in the county jail for a period not to exceed five days each day in which any violation is continued beyond the aforesaid notice time limit shall be deemed a separate offense    liability to city for losses any person violating any provision of this chapter shall become liable to the city for any expense loss or damage occasioned by reason of such violation which the city may suffer as a result thereof    damage recovery the city shall have the right of recovery from all persons any expense incurred by such system for the repair or replacement of any sewer pipe damaged in any manner by any person by the performance of any work under their control or by any negligent acts    penalties any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or rules or regulations of the city or who shall connect a service pipe or discharge without first having obtained a permit therefor  or who shall violate any provisions of the wisconsin statutes wisconsin administrative or any other materials which are incorporated by reference shall upon conviction thereof forfeit an amount as provided in the general penalty section of this code of ordinances in costs of prosecution this however shall not bar the city from enforcing the connection duties set out in the provisions of this chapter for mandatory hookup    definitions unless the context specifically indicates otherwise the meaning of terms used in this chapter shall be as follows approved means approved by the common councils public works committee or its designated agent biochemical oxygen demand bod means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter in five days at twenty 20 degrees centigrade expressed as milligrams per liter quantitative determination of bod shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in the most recent edition of standard methods building means a structure having walls and a roof erected or set upon an individual foundation or slabconstructed base designed or used for the housing shelter enclosure or support of persons animals or property of any kind for purposes of this chapter each structure abutting another structure which does not have an approved ingressegress doorway basement foundation walls or structures which separate exterior or exterior abutting walls or public use structures separated by an unpierced firewall shall be considered as a separate or individual building building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer by gravity flow building inspector means the building inspector of the city of sun prairie or such persons appointed assistant agent or representative building sewer means that portion of the plumbing system beginning at the immediate outside foundation or proposed foundation wall to its connection with the main of a public sewer private sewers private sewage system or other point of disposal city means the city of sun prairie wisconsin committee or public works committee means the public works committee for the city of sun prairie or such persons appointed agent or representative compatible pollutants means biochemical oxygen demand suspended solids phosphorus or ph plus additional pollutants identified in the wpdes permit for the publicly owned treatment works receiving the pollutants if such works were designed to create such additional pollutants to a substantial degree connection charge means a one time charge to a new sanitary sewer user the proceeds of which shall be placed in a special escrow account to offset future plant expansion costs debt service mean costs to the sewer department for the retirement of debts incurred in the provision of wastewater facilities including both principal and interest decontaminated water means groundwater or surface water that has been contaminated by one or more hazardous substances as defined in wisconsin statutes and regulations adopted pursuant thereto but which subsequent to such contamination has been treated in accordance with a plan of treatment approved by the wisconsin department of natural resources and approved for discharge following such treatment pursuant to a wpdes permit pursuant to a remedial action plan or otherwise floatable oil means oil fat or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility a wastewater or septage shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system garbage means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation cooking and dispensing of food and from the handling storage and sales of meat fish fowl fruits vegetables and condemned food industrial user means 1 a any nongovernmental nonresidential user of a publicly owned treatment works which discharges more than the equivalent of twentyfive thousand 25000 gallons per day gpd of sanitary waste and which is identified in the standard industrial classification manual 197 office of management and budget as amended and supplemented under one of the following divisions division a agriculture forestry and fishing  division b mining  division d manufacturing  division e transportation communications electric gas and sanitary services  b division i services i the city will exclude domestic waste or discharges from sanitary conveniences for determining industrial wastes ii after applying the sanitary waste exclusion in subsection 1ai of this section discharges in the above divisions that have a volume exceeding twentyfive thousand 25000 gpd or the weight of biochemical oxygen demand bod or suspended solids ss equivalent to that weight found in twentyfive thousand 25000 gpd of sanitary waste are considered industrial users sanitary waste for purposes of this calculation of equivalency shall be wastes of normal concentration as defined in this chapter 2 any nongovernmental user who discharges wastewater to the citys sewers which wastewater contains toxic pollutants or poisonous solids liquids or gases in sufficient quantity either singly or by interaction with other waste to contaminate the sludge of the municipal sewer systems or to injure or to interfere with any sewage treatment process or which constitutes a hazard to humans or animals creates a public nuisance or creates any hazard in or has an adverse effect on the waters receiving any discharge from the treatment works 3 all commercial users or an individual system constructed with grant assistance under h of the federal water pollution control act and this section industrial wastes means wastes discharged by industrial users licensed disposer means a person holding a license under 3a wisconsin statutes natural outlet means any outlet including storm sewers into a watercourse pond ditch lake or other body of surface water or groundwater normal concentration means 1 fiveday twenty 20 degrees c bod of not more than two hundred 200 mgl  2 a suspended solids content of not more than two hundred fifty 250 mgl 3 a phosphorus concentration of not more than eight mgl normal wastewater means wastewater in which bod suspended solids or phosphorus concentrations do not exceed normal concentrations nuisance a nuisance under this section is referred to as any source of filth or probable human health hazard pursuant to the provisions of wisconsin statutes operation and maintenance means costs to the sewer department for the provision of labor utilities supplies equipment maintenance and other normal costs necessary for the provision of sewage service operation and maintenance includes replacement person means any and all persons including any individual firm company municipal or private corporation association society institution enterprise government agency or other entity ph means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration the concentration is the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution neutral water for example has a ph value of seven and a hydrogen ion concentration of 10 7  pretreatment means treating industrial wastes to remove or reduce the quantity or rate of discharge of one or more pollutants prior to discharge to the public sewer system when required by governmental regulation phosphorus is an element that is detected as phosphates in natural waters and wastewaters excessive quantities contribute to both detrimental and nuisance plant and aquatic life quantitative determination of phosphorus shall be made in accordance with one of the available procedures set forth in the most recent edition of standard methods properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers with no particle greater than onehalf inch 127 centimeters in any dimension public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights and is controlled by public authority replacement means expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment accessories or appurtenances which are necessary to maintain the capacity and performance during the service life of the treatment works for which such works were designed and constructed sanitary sewer means a sewer that carries liquid and watercarried wastes from residences commercial buildings industrial plants and institutions together with small quantities of ground storm and surface waters that are not admitted intentionally service pipe is the lateral connection pipe sewage is the spent water of a community the preferred term is municipal wastewater sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying wastewater sewer department or department means the sun prairie water pollution control department slug means any discharge of water or wastewater which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period longer than fifteen 15 minutes more than five times the average twentyfourhour concentration or flows during normal operation and shall adversely affect the collection system andor performance of the wastewater treatment works standard methods means the examination and analytical procedures set forth in the most recent edition of standard methods for the examination of water sewage and industrial wastes published jointly by the american public health association the american water works association and the water pollution control federation storm sewer means a sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage but excludes industrial wastes other than unpolluted cooling water or decontaminated water discharged pursuant to the approval of the city granted in accordance with this chapter suspended solids means total suspended matter that either floats on the surface of or is in suspension in water wastewater or other liquids and that is removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed in standard methods for the examination of water and wastewater as referred to as nonfilterable residue unpolluted water is water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided user charge or wastewater service charge means a charge levied on users of wastewater treatment works and the sanitary sewer system for the cost of operation and maintenance and debt service for such facilities the term operation and maintenance include replacement wastewater means the spent water of a community from the standpoint of sources it may be a combination of the liquid and watercarried wastes from residences commercial buildings industrial plants and institutions together with any groundwater surface water and storm water that may be present wastewater facilities means the structures equipment and processes required to collect carry away and treat domestic and industrial wastes and dispose of the effluent wastewater treatment works means an arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater industrial wastes and sludge sometimes used as synonymous with waste treatment plant or wastewater treatment plant or water pollution control plant watercourse means a natural or artificial channel for the passage of water either continuously or intermittently wisconsin pollutant discharge elimination system wpdes permit means a permit issued by the wisconsin state department of natural resources to any person pursuant to wisconsin statutes to permit the discharge of a pollutant into the waters of the state of wisconsin the citys wpdes permit shall mean the wpdes permit that established effluent limitations and monitoring requirements for the citys wastewater treatment work  2212006   2000  prior code  9390 stormwater utility purpose and necessityauthorization the city council of the city finds that the management of stormwater and other surface water discharges within the upper koshkonong creek yahara river and lake mendota watershed token creek and maunesha river watersheds is a matter that affects the health safety and welfare of the city its citizens and businesses and others in the surrounding area failure to effectively manage stormwater affects the sanitary sewer utility operations of the city by among other things increasing the likelihood of infiltration and inflow into the sanitary sewer system surface water runoff may cause erosion of lands threaten residences and businesses with water damage and create environmental damage to the rivers streams and other bodies of water within and adjacent to the city a system for the collection and disposal of stormwater provides services to all properties within the city and surrounding areas including those properties not currently serve by the systems the cost of operating and maintaining the city stormwater management system and financing necessary repairs replacements improvements and extensions thereof should to the extent practicable be allocated in relationship to the services received from the system in order to protect the health safety and welfare of the public the city council hereby exercises its authority to establish a stormwater utility and establish the rates for stormwater management services adopting and publishing as required by law the regulations contained in this chapter the city is acting pursuant to authority granted by chapters 62 and 66 wisconsin statutes  2002   creation there is hereby established a stormwater utility in the city the operation of the stormwater utility shall be under the supervision of the city council the city administrator or hisher designee will oversee and be in charge of the utility  2002   authority of the stormwater utility the city acting stormwater utility may acquire construct lease own operate maintain extend expand replace clean dredge repair conduct manage and finance such facilities operations and activities as are deemed by the city to be proper and reasonably necessary for a system of storm and surface water management these facilities may include without limitation due to enumeration surface and underground drainage facilities sewers watercourses retaining walls ponds basins streets roads ditches and such other facilities as will support a stormwater management system  2002   definitions in this chapter duplex means a residential dwelling having two dwelling units dwelling unit means a room or group of rooms providing or intended to provide living quarters for not more than one family equivalent runoff unit eru means the basic unit by which the stormwater utility charge is calculated under this chapter and is based upon the average impervious area of single family homes in the city on the date of adoption of this ordinance codified in this chapter one eru is three thousand four hundred sixtyeight square feet impervious area or impervious surface mean a surface measured on a horizontal plane which has been compacted or covered with a layer of material so that it is highly resistant to infiltration by rainwater or the runoff from snow melt it includes but is not limited to streets roofs sidewalks parking lots and other similar surfaces and semiimpervious surfaces such as highly compacted clay or gravel multifamily unit means any residential property comprised of three or more dwelling units nonresidential property means any developed lot or parcel not exclusively residential as defined herein including but not limited to transient rentals such as hotels and motels commercial industrial institutional governmental property and parking lots residential property means any lot or parcel developed exclusively for residential purposes including but not limited to single family homes manufactured homes multifamily apartment buildings and condominiums single family unit means any residential property including manufactured homes consisting of one dwelling unit stormwater conveyance system refers to the system of streets curbs gutters berms swales landscaping detention and retention ponds or basins pipes outfalls inlets and other components of city infrastructure owned andor maintained by the city for the purpose of managing gathering transmitting or conveying stormwater this term includes tributaries creeks rivers and streams improved by the city to enhance their ability to convey stormwater stormwater utility refers to the utility established under this chapter for the purpose of managing stormwater and imposing charges for the recovery of costs connected with such stormwater management stormwater utility charge means the fee imposed under this chapter for the rendering of stormwater utility services by the city undeveloped property means property that is not developed by the addition of an improvement such as a building structure change in grade addition of impervious surface or substantial landscaping a property shall be considered developed if 1 a certificate of occupancy has been issued for a building or structure on the property or if no certificate of occupancy has been issued upon substantial completion of construction or final inspection  or 2 construction of an improvement on a property is at least fifty percent 50% completed and such construction has ceased for a period of at least three 3 months whether consecutive or not  12182007   2002   connection whenever public ministorm sewers or storm laterals are laid along and within any public street alley or place in the city and ready for use property owners shall upon notice from the city connect to the facility provided to their particular property all connections shall be in a manner in accordance with the state plumbing of the property owner to connect within the time period specified in said notice shall result in said connection being made by the city and all charges being assessed against the property as a special charge  2002   stormwater utility rates a introduction the basis for computation of the charge for stormwater services and facilities provided by the stormwater utility to lots and parcels of land within the city is established under this section the actual rate of charges to be imposed and any future changes in those rates may be made by resolution all rates established pursuant to this chapter shall be fair and reasonable a schedule of current charges shall be maintained and on file in the office of the city clerk b 1 exemptions exemptions to the charges comprising the stormwater utility charge are established in recognition that in limited circumstances properties may not benefit directly from all services and facilities provided by the stormwater utility owners of property satisfying the following criteria may apply to the city for an exemption from the equivalent runoff unit as described in this section a discharges to surface water bodies if more than half as determined by the city engineer of a customers property drains directly into the upper koshkonong creek downstream from the koshkonong stormwater management facility yahara river and lake mendota watershed token creek maunesha river or any tributaries draining to these water bodies the city may upon customer request exempt the customer from a portion of the charge provided that i the discharge is direct and not portion of the stormwater conveyance system owned or operated by the stormwater utility and ii the drainage is not in violation of any environmental code or federal state or local surface water drainage requirements and all required permits for said discharges have been granted b from time to time the public works committee may adopt additional criteria under which owners may be eligible for exemptions to the charges comprising the stormwater utility charge 2 credits credits may be granted to owners of properties who have significantly reduced the impacts of stormwater discharge on the stormwater utility system owners of property which discharge all or a portion of their stormwater into privately owned and maintained stormwater facilities shall receive a prorated credit to the number of erus assigned to their property as determined by the city engineer no owner may be given a credit in excess of sixtyfive percent 65% of their total number of erus 3 prior to receiving a credit or exemption the city engineer or designee shall be allowed access to the property to determine the amount of credit or exemption to be granted  12182007   2002   billing a the city department of finance is hereby appointed as the collection agency for the city stormwater utility the city department of finance may contract for the billing and collection of stormwater fees the department of finance shall allocate the actual cost incurred of billing and collecting to the expense of systemwide management and administration of the stormwater utility b the bills for stormwater utility charges shall be mailed to the designated utility bill recipient but this mailing shall not relieve the owner of the property from liability for rental property in the event payment is not made as required in this article the owner of any property served which is occupied by tenants shall have the right to examine collection records of the city for the purpose of determining whether such rates and charges have been paid for such tenants provided that such examination shall be made at the office at which the records are kept and during the hours that such office is open for business c stormwater utility charges shall not be payable in installments if stormwater utility charges remain unpaid after a period of twenty 20 days from the date of utility bill such bill shall become a delinquent special charge and shall become a lien as provided in 4d  and  wisconsin statutes these charges shall automatically be extended upon the current or next tax roll as delinquent against the property and all proceedings in relation to the collection return and sale of property for delinquent real estate taxes shall apply to such special charges charges not paid within twenty 20 days of issuance shall be assessed a onetime three percent 3% late payment charge d all delinquent special charges shall be subject to a ten percent 10% penalty in addition to all other charges and prior penalties or interest when the delinquent special charge is extended upon the tax roll  832004   2002   customer classification a for the purposes of imposing the stormwater utility charge all lots and parcels within the city are classified into the following customer classes 1 residential  singlefamily home and mobile home  2 residential  duplex  3 residential  multifamily and condominium  4 nonresidential  or 5 undeveloped b the city engineer or designee shall prepare a list of lots and parcels within the city and assign one of the classifications provided in subsection a1 to each lot or parcel c the average square footage of impervious area for an average singlefamily home in the city equal to one eru shall be three thousand four hundred sixtyeight 3468 square feet d the charges imposed upon singlefamily and mobile home residential properties shall be the rate for one eru e the charges imposed upon duplex residential properties and condominiums of two units shall be the rate for sixtyfive percent 65% of one eru 65 for each unit f the charges imposed upon multifamily and condominiums with three units or more shall be the minimum rate of fourtenths 04 of one eru multiplied by the number of individual dwelling units existing on the property upon the owners request multifamily or mixed use properties may be treated as nonresidential properties as described in g provided the owner takes responsibility for the charge g the charges imposed upon nonresidential property shall be determined by a rate for one eru times a factor obtained by dividing the total impervious area of the nonresidential property by the square footage equivalent for one eru such impervious area shall be determined based on the best information reasonably available the result shall be rounded down to the nearest onetenth 01 actual square footage charge   of impervious surface x rate for 1 eru 3468 square feet h the charges imposed for undeveloped properties as defined herein shall be the rate for one eru multiplied by a factor established by resolution i the city engineer or designee shall be responsible for determining the impervious area based on the best available information including but not limited to data supplied by the city assessor aerial photography the property owner tenant or developer the city engineer or designee may require additional information as necessary to make the determination the city engineer or his designee shall be allowed access on reasonable notice to the property owner in order to conduct measurements in order to determine impervious area if access is denied impervious area shall be presumed to be ninetyfive percent 95% of the total square footage of the property the billing amount shall be updated by the city engineer or designee based on any additions to the impervious area as approved building permit process j the minimum charges for any nonresidential unit and multifamily unit shall be equal to the rate for fourtenths 04 of one eru unless it contains no impervious surface k all unoccupied developed lots and parcels with impervious surfaces shall be subject to a stormwater utility charge  12182007   2002   new construction a except for singlefamily units all new buildings shall be charged a portion of the established charge once a temporary electric meter has been installed or as determined by the city engineer the established charge shall begin once the water meter has been installed or as determined by the city engineer b on new singlefamily units the stormwater fee shall be charged at the time an application is made for water and light service  12182007   2002   method of appeal a the stormwater utility charge may be appealed as follows 1 a written appeal shall be filed with the city clerk prior to the stormwater utility charge due date  or 2 within thirty 30 days of payment a written challenge to the stormwater utility charge must be filed with the city clerk on behalf of the customer specifying all bases for the challenge and the amount of the stormwater utility charge the customer asserts is inappropriate failure to file a challenge within thirty 30 days of payment waives all right to later challenge the charge 3 the disputed charge shall be held in abeyance until the public works committee has made a determination pursuant to subsection b of this section b the public works committee
