watercourses and wetlands  e provide a set of performance standards that are consistent with the standards set forth by dane county  f achieve an eighty percent 80% reduction in sediment load rates to dane county waters compared to no controls for all new development a forty percent 40% reduction in sediment load rates compared to no controls for all redevelopment and street reconstruction and a twenty percent 20% reduction in sediment load rates compared to no controls for existing developments  g ensure no increase in temperature of stormwater postconstruction in order to protect coldwater communities  h ensure no increase in the rate of surface water drainage from sites during or after construction  and i protect public and private property from damage resulting from stormwater runoff  2002   applicability of requirement for stormwater management permits a unless otherwise exempted by a stormwater management permit shall be required and all stormwater management provisions of this chapter shall apply to any of the following activities within the city of sun prairie 1 any developments after  that results in the cumulative addition of twenty thousand 20000 square feet of impervious surface to the site 2 any development that requires a subdivision plat 3 any development that requires a certified survey map csm  for property intended for commercial or industrial use 4 any redevelopment as defined in shall meet the requirements specified within this chapter 5 other land development activities including but not limited to redevelopment or alteration of existing buildings and other structures that the city determines may significantly increase downstream runoff volumes flooding soil erosion water pollution or property damage or significantly impact a stream creek wetland area or body of water 6 agricultural development that creates new impervious surface area exceeding twenty thousand 20000 square feet on the site  3202007   6202006   2002   exemptions and clarifications a the following activities are exempt from all requirements of this chapter 1 any activity directly related to the planting growing and harvesting of agricultural crops 2 reserved b the following activities are exempt from the infiltration standards described in  1 redevelopment sites 2 new development sites with less than ten percent 10% connected imperviousness based on complete development of the post construction site provided the cumulative area of all impervious surface is less than one acre 3 agricultural facilities and practices 4 areas where the infiltration rate of the soil is less than 06 inches per hour measured at the bottom of the infiltration system where the soil layer is not easily removed or manipulated 5 parking areas and access roads less than five thousand 5000 square feet for commercial and industrial development 6 roads in commercial industrial and institutional land uses and arterial roads  6202006   2002   definitions for the purposes of these regulations the following terms phrases words and their derivations shall have the meaning given in this section when not inconsistent with the context words used in the present tense include the future words in the plural number include the singular and vice versa for each the use of the word shall in these definitions and throughout the text of this title is always mandatory and not merely suggestive the following definitions shall be applicable in this title administering authority means the city employee or departmentss agent or designee empowered to administer this chapter affected means that a regulated activity has significantly a caused negative impacts on water quality or the use or maintenance of land or business  or b endangered health safety or general welfare agricultural land use means use of land for planting growing cultivating and harvesting of crops for human or livestock consumption and pasturing or yarding of livestock applicant means any person who applies for a permit to undertake activities governed by this chapter average annual rainfall means measured precipitation in madison wisconsin between march 12 and  bank erosion means the removal of soil or rock fragments along the banks or bed of a stream channel resulting from high flow after rain events best management practices means a practice technique or measure that is an effective practical means of preventing or reducing soil erosion or water pollution or both from runoff both during and after land development activities these can include structural vegetative or operational practices business day means a day which the citys offices are routinely and customarily open for business  means title 15 of the sun prairie ordinances city means the incorporated city of sun prairie wisconsin and all lands within the boundaries thereof cold water community means surface waters capable of supporting a community of coldwater fish and other aquatic life or serving as a spawning area for cold water fish species nr 102043a wisconsin administrative  connected imperviousness means an impervious surface that is directly connected to a separate storm sewer or water of the state via an impervious flow path effective infiltration area means the area of the infiltration system that is used to infiltrate runoff and does not include the area used for site access berms or pretreatment existing development means buildings and other structures and impervious area existing prior to  fill means any act by which earth sand gravel rock or any other material is deposited placed replaced pushed dumped pulled transported or moved to a new location and shall include the resulting conditions financial security instrument means a surety bond performance bond maintenance bond irrevocable letter of credit or similar guarantees submitted to the city finance directorcity treasurer to assure that requirement of the ordinance are carried out in compliance with the stormwater management plan hydrologic soil group hsg means has the meaning used in the runoff calculation methodology promulgated by the united states natural resources conservation service engineering field manual for conservation practices impervious surface means a surface that releases the rainfall as surface runoff during a large portion of the design rainfall event rooftops sidewalks gravel and pavement parking lots and street surfaces are examples of impervious surfaces infiltration for the purpose of this chapter refers to any precipitation that does not leave the site as surface runoff infiltration system means a device or practice such as a basin trench rain garden or swale designed specifically to encourage infiltration but does not include natural infiltration in pervious surfaces such as lawns redirecting of rooftop downspouts onto lawns or minimal infiltration from practices such as swales or road side channels designed for conveyance and pollutant removal only karst feature means an area or surficial geologic feature subject to bedrock dissolution so that it is likely to provide a conduit to groundwater and may include caves enlarged fractures mine features exposed bedrock surfaces sinkholes springs seeps or swallets lightly disturbed site means a site where an area of land is subjected to minor compaction due to the limited removal of vegetative cover or earthmoving activities maximum extent practicable mep means a level of implementing best management practices in order to achieve a performance standard specified in this chapter which takes into account the best available technology cost effectiveness and other competing issues such as human safety and welfare endangered and threatened resources historic properties and geographic features mep allows flexibility in the way to meet standards and may vary based on the performance standard and site conditions new development means any of the following a structural development including construction of a new building or other structures b expansion or alteration of an existing structure that results in an increase in the surface dimension of the building or structure c landdisturbing activities  or d creation or expansion of impervious surface nonerosive velocity means a rate of flow of stormwater runoff usually measured in feet per second that does not erode soils nonerosive velocities vary for individual sites taking into account topography soil type and runoff rates peak flows means the maximum rate of flow of water at a given point in a channel watercourse or conduit resulting from the predetermined storm or flood permit means written authorization made by the city engineer or their designee to the applicant approving the stormwater management plan required in order too account for the activities outlined in section p permit administrative fee means a sum of money paid to the city by the permit applicant for the purpose of recouping the cityrelated expenses incurred by the city in administering the permit pervious surface means any land cover that permits rain or melting snow to soak into the ground plan means a stormwater management plan required by this chapter plan review agency means the city of sun prairie engineering department staff or contracted entity charged by the city of sun prairie with the responsibility of reviewing stormwater management plans required under this chapter plat review officer means the city of sun prairie engineering department staff or contracted entity charged by the city of sun prairie with the responsibility of reviewing land divisions certified survey maps or subdivision plats or any combination thereof under of the wisconsin statutes postdevelopment means this term refers to the extent and distribution of land cover types anticipated to occur under conditions of full development that will influence the rainfall runoff and infiltration this term is used to match pre and postdevelopment stormwater peak flows as required by the chapter predevelopment means this term refers to the extent and distribution of land cover types present before the initiation of the proposed land development activity assuming that all land uses prior to landdisturbing activity are in good con dition as described in the natural resources conservation service technical release 55 urban hydrology for small watersheds commonly referred to as tr55 this term is used to match predevelopment and postdevelopment stormwater peak flows as required by this chapter in the situation where cumulative impervious surface created after  exceeds the twenty thousand 20000 square foot threshold the predevelopment conditions shall be those prior to the proposed land disturbance principle responsible party means individual person assigned by the property owner to be responsible for installing and maintaining stormwater management improvements recharge means the portion of the average annual rainfall that infiltrates the soil and becomes groundwater recharge does not include evaporation transpiration or runoff from the site redevelopment means any construction alteration or improvement exceeding four thousand 4000 square feet of land disturbance performed on sites where the existing site is predominantly developed as commercial industrial institutional or multifamily residential uses projects may include a mix or redevelopment and new impervious surfaces new impervious surfaces added as a result of redevelopment are subject to runoff means the rainfall snowmelt or irrigation water flowing over the ground surface runoff curve number rcn means this has the meaning used in the runoff calculation methodology promulgated by the united states natural resources conservation practices sediment means solid earth material both mineral and organic that is in suspension is being transported or has been moved from its site of origin by air water gravity or ice and has come to rest on the earths surface at a different site sedimentation means the deposition of eroded soils at a site different from the on where the erosion occurred site means the entire area included in the legal description of the land on which the development activity is proposed stop work order means an order issued by the engineering or building inspection departments which requires that all construction activity on the site be stopped storm events means the precipitation amounts that occur over a twentyfour 24 hour period that have a specified recurrence interval for dane county wisconsin for example oneyear twoyear fiveyear tenyear twentyfiveyear and one hundredyear storm events mean the precipitation amounts that occur over a twentyfourhour period that have a recurrence interval of one two five ten 10 twentyfive 25 and one hundred 100 years respectively stormwater means the flow of water which results from and occurs during and immediately following a rainfall snowmelt or icemelt event stormwater management means any measures taken to permanently reduce or minimize the negative impacts of stormwater runoff quantity and quality after land development activities street reconstruction means removal and replacement of the roadbed where existing stormwater conveyance systems are modified structure means any humanmade object with form shape and utility either permanently or temporarily attached to placed upon or set into the ground stream bed or lake bed unnecessary hardship means that circumstance where special conditions which were not selfcreated affect a particular property and make strict conformity with regulation unnecessary burdensome or unreasonable in light of the purposes of this chapter  3202007   6202006   2002   stormwater management permit and administration a no activity meeting the criteria described in occur and no zoning permit may be issued until the city of sun prairie engineering department issues a stormwater management permit b the applicant must provide the following when requesting a permit 1 if a submittal for a stormwater management permit is submitted by someone other than the landowner the submittal must include the name and address of the agent that will be bound by the terms of this chapter and who will be responsible for reimbursement of the costs associated with the permit 2 if a landowner appoints an agent to submit a stormwater management plan the landowner shall be bound by the requirements of this chapter and the terms of any permit issued to the agent 3 copies of permits or permit applications or approvals required by any other governmental entity 4 a proposed schedule for completion and installation of all elements of an approved stormwater management plan 5 evidence if required by the city of financial responsibility to complete the work proposed in the approved plan the city may require a financial security instrument sufficient to guarantee completion of the project c the approval process shall consist of the following 1 the applicant shall forward two copies of the stormwater management submittal for review to the city engineers office and two copies to the citys plan review agency the review staff shall review the submittal for compliance with requirements of this chapter 2 within the timeframe listed below the plan review staff shall either approve the submitted plan or notify the applicant of any deficiencies a parcels less than two acres within twenty 20 days of receiving the required information the city engineer or its designee shall review the submittal and notify the applicant whether the application is approved disapproved conditionally approved or whether additional information is required b parcels greater than two acres within fortyfive 45 days of receiving the required information the city engineer or its designee shall review the submittal and notify the applicant whether the application is approved disapproved conditionally approved or whether additional information is required 3 for all applications the review staff may request comments from other city departments and other governmental agencies 4 where stormwater management practices are to be privately owned an affidavit that describes the property by legal description notifying future prospective purchasers of the timetables and potential liability imposed for failure to bring the property into compliance with this chapter after notification shall be recorded with the dane county register of deeds by the applicant this information shall also be noted on plats and certified survey maps 5 permit approvals shall be valid for a period of one hundred eighty 180 days from the date of issuance unless otherwise noted in the initial approval the reviewing official may extend the permit for a period of time needed to complete construction the extension may be contingent upon meeting additional conditions in order to account for changes to the citys stormwater ordinance d conditions of the permit shall be as follows 1 the plan shall be implemented prior to the start of any land disturbing or construction activity stormwater management components of the plan shall be maintained in perpetuity 2 the permittee is responsible for successful completion of the stormwater management plan the permittee shall be liable for all costs incurred including environmental restoration costs resulting from noncompliance with an approved plan 3 application for a stormwater permit shall constitute express permission by the permittee and landowner for the city engineer or their designee to enter the property for the purposes of inspection or curative action e inspections 1 submittal for a stormwater management permit shall constitute express permission by the permittee and landowner for the city engineer or their designee to enter upon the property prior to construction and inspect conditions of the property and for inspections during the construction phase to assure compliance with the ordinance and approved plan 2 within ten 10 days after installation of all practices in an approved stormwater management plan the permittee shall notify the city engineer or their designee and the citys plan review agency changes to the approved plan must be approved by the plan review staff prior to implementation changes to the approved plan will result in the resubmittal of record drawings that clearly indicates the changes from the approved plan 3 upon ten 10 days notice of completion by the permittee the city engineer or their designee shall inspect the property to verify compliance with the approved plan 4 maintenance is the responsibility of the owner and the stormwater management facilities are subject to periodic inspections and orders for repairs as required by the plan review staff f conditions of a stormwater management permit transfer are as follows 1 when a permittee and landowner act to transfer an interest in property subject to an approved stormwater management plan prior to completion of the approved improvements the permittee must secure approval from the plan review staff or be subject to resubmittal for consideration of approval 2 when a permittee and landowner transfers ownership possession or control of real estate subject to an uncompleted stormwater management plan the successor in interest to any portion of the real estate shall be responsible to control runoff and shall comply with the minimum standards provided in this chapter 3 when ownership possession or control of property subject to an uncompleted stormwater management plan is transferred the former owner seller shall notify the new owner buyer as to the current status of compliance with notice to the city engineers office and provide the buyer with a copy of the approved stormwater management plan 4 transfer of interest in real estate subject to an approved uncompleted stormwater management plan may be conducted consistent with this chapter under any of the following arrangements a the transferee shall file a new approved stormwater management plan or with the city  b the transferee shall obtain an approved assignment from the city engineer or their designee as subpermittee to complete that portion of the approved plan regulating runoff on the transferees property c the city may require the permittee to provide the city of sun prairie with a duly completed and executed continuing surety bond or certified check in an amount sufficient to complete the work proposed in the approved plan if the transferor enters into escrow agreements with transferees to complete the approved plan these funds shall be available to the city to attain plan compliance if the approved plan is not completed the city may use the surety bond to complete the remaining work to achieve compliance with the plan g plan or permit amendments any proposed modifications to an approved plan construction schedule or alterations to accepted construction sequencing shall be approved by the city engineer and the citys review agency prior to implementation of the changes  8182009   2002   stormwater management plan requirements a stormwater management plans shall satisfy all requirements of this chapter b stormwater management plans shall at a minimum include the following information 1 a narrative describing the proposed project including implementation schedule for the planned improvements 2 identification of the entity responsible for longterm maintenance of the stormwater management facilities 3 a map showing the drainage areas for each watershed 4 a summary of runoff peak flow rate calculations by watershed area including a preexisting peak flow rates b postconstruction peak flow rates with no detention c postconstruction peak flow rates with detention d assumed runoff curve numbers rcns e time of concentration tc used in calculations 5 a complete site plan and specifications signed by the person who designed the plan all plans shall be drawn to an easily legible scale shall be clearly labeled and shall include at a minimum all the following information a property line and lot numbers b all buildings and outdoor uses existing and proposed including all dimensions and setbacks c all public and private roads interior roads driveways and parking lots show traffic patterns and type of paving and surfacing material d all natural and artificial water features including but not limited to lakes ponds streams including intermittent streams and ditches show ordinary high water marks of all navigable waters one hundred 100 year flood elevations and delineated wetland boundaries if any if not available appropriate flood zone determination or wetland delineation or both may be required at the applicants expense e depth to bedrock f depth to seasonal high water table g the extent and location of all soil types as described in the dane county soil survey slopes exceeding twelve percent 12% and areas of natural woodland or prairie h existing and proposed elevations referenced to the city of sun prairie datum and existing and proposed contours in the area requiring a grading and filling permit i elevation sections profiles and details as needed to describe all natural and artificial features of the project j soil erosion control and overland runoff control measures including runoff calculations as appropriate k detailed construction schedule l copies of permits or permit applications required by any other governmental entities or agencies m any other information necessary to reasonably determine the location nature and condition of any physical or environmental features n location of all stormwater management facilities o all existing and proposed drainage features p the location and area of all existing and proposed impervious surfaces q the limits of and area of disturbed area 6 engineered designs for all structural management practices 7 a description of methods to control oil and grease or written justification for not providing such control 8 if required by the city a description and plans to control temperature of runoff 9 a maintenance plan and schedule for all permanent stormwater management practices as recorded on the affidavit required in c4 c the submitted plan shall include stormwater management performance standards proposed design suggested location and phased implementation of effective practicable stormwater management measures for plans shall be designed engineered and implemented to achieve the following results 1 sediment control a for new development design practices to retain soil particles greater than five microns on the site eighty percent 80% reduction resulting from a 1year 24hour storm event 249 inches over 24hour duration according to approved procedures and assuming no sediment resuspension b for redevelopment resulting in exposed surface parking lots and associated traffic areas design practices to retain soil particles greater than 20 microns on the entire site forty percent 40% reduction resulting from a 1year 24hour storm event according to approved procedures and assuming no sediment resuspension under no circumstances shall the sites existing sediment control level or trapping efficiency be reduced as a result of the redevelopment 2 oil and grease control for all stormwater plans for commercial or industrial developments and all other uses where the potential for pollution by oil or grease or both exists the first onehalf inch of runoff will be treated using the best oil and grease removal technology available this requirement may be waived by the plan reviewer only when the applicant can demonstrate that installation of such practices is not necessary 3 runoff rate controlhydrologic calculations all runoff calculations shall be according to the methodology described in the natural resources conservation services technical release 55 urban hydrology for small watersheds commonly referred to as tr55 or other methodology approved by the dane county conservationist for agricultural land subject to this section the maximum runoff curve number rcn used in such calculations shall be 51 for hsg a 68 for hydrologic soil group b 78 for hsg c and 83 for hsg d the tr55 specified curve numbers for other land uses in heavily disturbed sites will be lowered one permeability class for hydrologic calculations lightly disturbed areas require no modification where practices have been implemented to restore soil structure to predeveloped conditions no permeability class modification is required 4 runoff rate controldesign standards except for redevelopment projects all stormwater facilities shall be designed installed and maintained to effectively accomplish the following a maintain the predevelopment peak runoff rates for the 2year and 5year 24hour storm event 284 inches and 349 inches respectively over 24 hours duration using the nrcs mse4 storm distribution b limit the postdevelopment peak runoff rate for the 10year year 24hour storm event 409 inches and 501 inches respectively to the 5year predevelopment runoff rate over 24hour duration using the nrcs mse4 storm distribution c maintain the predevelopment peak runoff rates for the 100year 24hour storm event 666 inches over 24hour duration using the nrcs mse4 storm distribution without inundating buildings on local streets the depth of water at the crown of the street shall not exceed six inches on arterial streets and in commercial zoning districts the water level shall not exceed the top of curb elevation and the center twelve 12 feet of the street shall not be inundated 5 outlets discharges from new construction sites must have a stable outlet as determined by the city engineer capable of carrying designed flow at a nonerosive velocity outlet design must consider flow capacity and flow duration this requirement applies to both the site outlet and the ultimate outlet to stormwater conveyance or water body 6 infiltration a residential development for residential developments design practices to infiltrate sufficient runoff volume so that postdevelopment infiltration volume shall be at least ninety percent 90% of the predevelopment infiltration volume based upon average annual rainfall if when designing appropriate infiltration systems more than two percent 2% of the site is required to be used as effective infiltration area the applicant may alternately design infiltration systems and pervious surfaces to meet or exceed the estimated average annual recharge rate the annual predevelopment recharge rate shall be determined from the wisconsin geological and natural history surveys 2009 report groundwater recharge in dane county estimated by a gisbased waterbalanced model or subsequent updates to this report or by a sitespecific analysis using other appropriate techniques if this alternative design approach is taken at least two percent 2% of the site must be used for infiltration b nonresidential development for nonresidential development including commercial industrial and institutional development design practices to infiltrate sufficient runoff volume so that postdevelopment infiltration volume shall be at least ninety percent 90% of the predevelopment infiltration volume based on average annual rainfall if when designing appropriate infiltration systems more than two percent 2% of the site is required to be used as effective infiltration area the applicant may alternately design infiltration systems and pervious surfaces to meet or exceed the estimated average annual recharge rate the annual predevelopment recharge rate shall be determined from the wisconsin geological and natural history surveys 2009 report groundwater recharge in dane county estimated by a gisbased waterbalanced model or subsequent updates to this report or by a sitespecific analysis using other appropriate techniques if this alternative design approach is taken at least two percent 2% of the site must be used for infiltration c pretreatment before infiltrating runoff pretreatment shall be required for parking lot runoff and for runoff from new road construction in commercial industrial and institutional areas that will enter an infiltration system the pretreatment shall be designed to protect the infiltration system from clogging prior to scheduled maintenance and protect groundwater quality d prohibitions notwithstanding subparagraphs a infiltration systems may not be installed in any of the following areas i areas associated with tier 1 industrial facilities identified in 212a wisconsin administrative including storage loading rooftop and parking ii storage and loading areas of tier 2 industrial facilities identified in 212b wisconsin administrative fueling and vehicle maintenance areas iv areas within one thousand 1000 feet upgradient or within one hundred 100 feet downgradient of karst features v areas with less than three feet separation distance from bottom of the infiltration system to the elevation of seasonal high groundwater or the top of bedrock except that this provision does not prohibit infiltration of roof runoff vi areas with runoff from industrial commercial and institutional parking lots and roads and residential roads with less than five feet separation distance from the bottom of the infiltration system to the elevation of seasonal high groundwater of the top of bedrock vii areas within four hundred 400 feet of a community water system well as specified in 164 wisconsin administrative for runoff infiltrated from commercial industrial and institutional land uses or regional devices for residential development viii areas where contaminants of concern as defined in 032 wisconsin administrative are present in the soil infiltration will occur ix any area where the soil does not exhibit one of the following characteristics between the bottom of the infiltration system and the seasonal high groundwater and top of bedrock at least a fivefoot soil layer with ten percent 10% fines or greater this provision does not apply where soil medium within the infiltration system provides an equivalent level of protection and does not prohibit infiltration of roof runoff e alternate use of runoff where alternate uses of runoff are employed such as for toilet flushing laundry or irrigation such alternate use shall be given equal credit toward the infiltration volume required by this section f minimizing groundwater pollution according to wisconsin administrative infiltration systems designed in accordance with this section shall to the extent technically and economically feasible minimize the level of pollutants infiltrating to groundwater and shall maintain compliance with the preventative action limit at a point of standards application in accordance with wisconsin administrative if sitespecific information indicates that compliance with the preventative action limit is not achievable the infiltration system may not be installed or shall be modified to prevent infiltration to the maximum extent practicable 7 thermal control the stormwater management plan shall include provisions and practices to reduce the temperature of runoff for sites located within the watershed of river or stream identified by the wisconsin department of natural resources as a a cold water community as identified 043a nr 104 wisconsin administrative class i class ii and class iii trout streams identified in wisconsin trout streams dnr publication pubfh8062002 or its successor b rivers or streams proposed by the wisconsin department of natural resources as cold water communities and class i ii and iii trout streams 8 thermal controlcontinued a the stormwater management plan does not have to meet the requirement if the applicant can justify by use of a model approved by the dane county conservationist that practices are not necessary because the temperature increase of runoff from the site postdevelopment will be zero b a current list and maps of affected watersheds is available for reference at the dane county land conservation office 9 stormwater management goals the following standards shall be met whenever possible and proposed design suggested location and implementation of practices to meet these goals shall be included in plans a for existing development design practices to retain soil particles greater than forty 40 microns on the site twenty percent 20% reduction resulting from a oneyear twentyfour 24 hour storm event according to approved procedures and assuming no sediment resuspension b for street reconstruction design practices to retain soil particles greater than twenty 20 microns on the site forty percent 40% reduction resulting from a oneyear twentyfour hour storm event according to approved procedures and assuming no sediment resuspension  1192016   4212015   10212014   3202007   6202006   2002   offsite stormwater management a offsite stormwater management is allowed provided that all of the following conditions for the offsite facility are met 1 the offsite facility is in place 2 the offsite facility is designed and adequately sized to provide a level of stormwater management that at least meet the standards of this chapter 3 the existing offsite facility has a legally obligated entity responsible for its longterm operation and maintenance  2002   enforcement the city engineer or building inspector or their designee shall cause the enforcement of this chapter a the inspecting official acting on behalf of the city of sun prairie may post a stopwork order on projects under construction for any of the following reasons 1 any activity subject to this chapter is being undertaken without a stormwater management permit 2 the stormwater management permit is not being implemented in good faith 3 any permit holder fails to comply with any applicable stormwater management requirement set forth in any applicable permit or regulations of the wisdnr or other governmental regulating agency b if the permittee on projects under construction does not cease the activity or comply with the stormwater management plan or permit conditions within twentyfour 24 hours the plan commission or the inspecting official may request that the city attorney obtain a stop work order c it shall be a violation of this chapter for the unauthorized removal of any work stop order d the inspecting official or the public works committee acting upon a properly presented appeal may retract the stopwork order or the permit revocation e seventytwo 72 hours after posting a stopwork order the inspecting official may issue to the permittee or landowner or land user a notice of the citys intent to perform work necessary to comply with this chapter authorized agents of the city may go on the property and commence the work beginning at any time after twentyfour 24 hours after issuing the notice of intent the cost of the work performed by the city plus interest at a rate of five percent 5% over the citys borrowing rate then in effect shall be billed to the permittee or the landowner in the event a permittee or landowner fails to pay the amount due the city clerk shall enter the amount due on the tax rolls and the city shall proceed to collect the unpaid amounts as a special tax against the land f permittees or landowners who fail to maintain stormwater management facilities approved as part of their permit may be subject to revocation of their permit civil forfeiture and the conditions outlined in subsection e g any person violating any of the provision of this chapter shall be subject upon conviction to a civil forfeiture as provided below and shall be liable to pay the costs of prosecution for each violation each day a violation exists shall constitute a separate offense 1 first offense a forfeiture of not less than two hundred dollars $20000 nor more than five hundred dollars $50000 together with the costs of prosecution and any costs incurred by the city in connection with the claims of third parties and costs associated with any work required to bring the site into full compliance with this chapter 2 second offense a forfeiture of not less than five hundred dollars $50000 nor more than one thousand dollars $100000 together with the costs of prosecution and any costs incurred by the city in connection with the claims of third parties and costs associated with any work required to bring the site into full compliance with this chapter 3 subsequent offenses a forfeiture of not less than one thousand dollars $100000 nor more than one thousand seven hundred fifty dollars $175000 together with the costs of prosecution and any costs incurred by the city in connection with the claims of third parties and costs associated with any work required to bring the site into full compliance with this chapter h the city may also obtain an injunction to enforce the provisions of this chapter  2002   appeals and variances a appeals 1 any person aggrieved by any decision of the review staff or inspecting official pursuant to this chapter may appeal to the citys public works committee such appeal shall be taken within thirty 30 days after the challenged decision is issued in writing notice of appeal setting forth the specific grounds for the appeal shall be filed with the city engineers office and the public works committee the city engineer shall forthwith transmit the public works committee the record upon which the action appealed from was taken 2 the public works committee shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal and publish a class 2 notice thereof under wisconsin statutes as well as give due note to the parties in interest and decide the same within a reasonable time upon the hearing any party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney 3 the public works committee may in conformity with the provisions of this chapter reverse or affirm wholly or partly or modify the order requirement decision or determination appealed from and may make such order requirement decision or determination as ought to be made and shall have all the powers of the officer from whom the appeal is taken 4 the concurring vote of a majority of the public works committee shall be necessary to reverse the decision of the review staff or inspecting official b variances 1 an applicant may include in the submittal a request for a variance from the requirements of no variance shall be granted unless the applicant demonstrates and the review staff after consultation with the county conservationist finds that all of the following conditions are present a enforcement of the standards set forth in this chapter will result in unnecessary hardship to the landowner b the hardship is due to exceptional physical conditions unique to the property c granting the variance will not adversely affect the public health safety and welfare nor be contrary to the spirit purpose and intent of this chapter d the project will have no impact upon any of the stated purposes of this chapter as set forth in e the applicant has proposed an alternative to the requirement from which the variance is sought that will provide equivalent protection of the public health safety and welfare the environment and public and private property f the net cumulative effect of the variance will not impact downstream conditions g the citys stormwater management plan review staff determines that existing regional facilities exist that will account for the performance standards of this chapter 2 if all the conditions for granting a variance are met a variance may only be granted to the minimum extent necessary to afford relief from the unnecessary hardship with primary consideration to water quality and impact to downstream conditions 3 a variance from the provisions of c1 2 and 8 may only be granted if a the applicant has met the requirements of b1 b the applicant will be denied all reasonable and beneficial use of the property if the variance is denied 4 a person aggrieved by a variance determination by the citys stormwater management plan review staff may appeal the decision to the citys public works committee  6202006   2002   fees for permit administration a applicants for a stormwater management permit covered under this chapter shall pay a permit administration fee the cost for this fee shall be collected based on the following criteria 1 projects that do not result in a cumulative addition of twenty thousand 20000 square feet of impervious surface to the site but meets any of the other criteria listed in  projects that result in a cumulative addition of more than twenty thousand 20000 square feet of impervious surface 3 projects covered by a development agreement between the city of sun prairie and a developer or landowner these projects shall be subject to the permit administration fee under this chapter but the developer or landowner shall not be responsible under the development agreement for all costs associated with the review of the project and inspection of the implementation of the project b included in the permit administration fee are all cost incurred by city plan review and all costs associated with inspection of the construction stormwater management facilities   12192017    2002   schedule for permit administration fees a schedule of the stormwater management permit administration fee is available from the city engineering department the common council shall have the authority and discretion to make other adjustments to the permit administration fee   12192017    2002   technical standards and specifications the design of all best management practices designed to meet the requirements of this subchapter shall comply with the following technical standards a natural resources conservation services wisconsin field office technical guide  or its successor  b applicable construction or erosion control standards by the wisconsin department of natural resources  c any other technical methodology approved by the city of sun prairie  6202006 roadway naming and property addressing and displaying standards title and purpose a title this chapter shall be known as the roadway naming and property addressing and displaying standards b the purpose of these regulations is to establish a uniform system for assigning and displaying roadway names and property addresses for land within the corporate limits and extraterritorial plat approval jurisdiction of the city in order to promote the public health safety and general welfare of the community the roadway naming and property addressing and displaying standards are designed to further the efficient delivery of emergency and other public services by providing consistency lessening confusion and providing more timely and accurate information to service providers  part   definitions for the purposes of these regulations the following terms phrases words and their derivations shall have the meaning given in this section when not inconsistent with the context words used in the present tense include the future words in the plural number include the singular and vice versa for each the use of the word shall in these definitions and throughout the text of this title is always mandatory and not merely suggestive the following definitions shall be applicable in this title addressable roadway means a roadway that is dedicated to the public addressing plan means a document prepared and submitted by a subdivider displaying an address for each proposed lot and outlot in a proposed subdivision as required by the subdivision alley means a roadway that is either public or private and affords only secondary access to abutting properties an alley is not an addressable roadway base line means the northsouth or eastwest line used as a starting point for address numbers in the city property address numbering grid system in the city of sun prairie the base lines are bristol street and main streets contrasting means a striking difference  unlikeness  opposite directional prefix means a prefix assigned to a roadway based on its overall direction and its location within a grid system the directional prefix is not part of the roadway name directional prefixes may be n s e or w only origin means the point where the property address numbering grid base lines intersect in the city of sun prairie the base lines cross at the intersection of bristol street and main streets private roadway means private drives as described in f6 and private street as described in l and does not mean private common driveway as described in c2b proper door means the main door for a visitor or guest to access andor enter a structure property address means the property address is a number assigned to or approved by the city property addressing authority to an individual building dwelling unit or parcel addresses shall be no fewer than three characters and no more than four characters property addresses shall not be repeated on any roadway property address numbering grid means the virtual guide system used to meter out the address ranges for the city in groups of one hundred 100 public roadway means a roadway dedicated to the public and having rightofway roadway means a public way for pedestrians and vehicular traffic and utility access including but not limited to highways thoroughfares parkways roads streets avenues boulevards lanes places and courts and any pavements turf fixtures facilities structures plantings signs and other elements of the rightofway roadway name means the official name of a roadway which does not include the directional prefix or suffix roadway type suffix means a descriptive qualifier at the end of a roadway name typically describes the roadway type eg avenue place drive street means a roadway except when used as a roadway type suffix eg dewey street subdivision information spreadsheet means a twodimensional data table prepared and submitted by a subdivider containing certain elements as required by the subdivision  part   roadway naming and property addressing procedures a requirement for naming 1 all public and private roadways within the city shall be named in accordance with the roadway naming standards 2 plats within the citys extraterritorial jurisdiction etj shall include roadways names since the city provides some emergency services in the towns roadway names within the etj will be reviewed by the city to ensure there is no duplication of or confusion with roadway names in the city 3 private driveways must not be signed the purpose of this is to avoid confusion with private or public roadways b requirement for property addressing addresses shall be assigned to all lots within the city including outlots all lots shall have an address the addresses shall be assigned in accordance with the property addressing standards c departments responsible for approving newly assigned or changed roadway names and assigned property addresses 1 the roadway naming authority shall review proposed roadway names the roadway naming authority shall be the department of planning and economic development fire department emergency medical services police department and sun prairie public safety communications center representatives shall also review the proposed roadway names to ensure they are acceptable within their respective service areas 2 property addresses shall be reviewed and approved by the property addressing authority 3 the property addressing authority shall be the building inspection department d department responsible for coordination of roadway name and property address assignments 1 the information technology department shall be responsible for coordination of the data with the sun prairie public safety communications center systems the citys integrated database and dane county 2 a list of official roadway names will be prepared and maintained by the information technology department the official roadway names list shall contain both public and private roadways within the corporate limit and within the citys extraterritorial jurisdiction e how roadway naming and property addressing assignments shall be initiated 1 when a new roadway is proposed within the city whether public or private the names and addresses can be assigned and initiated in one or more of the following ways a preliminary plat for major subdivision in accordance with c of the subdivision roadway names are required on the preliminary plat for a major subdivision the roadway names proposed on the preliminary plat will be reviewed by the roadway naming authority and ultimately approved by the city council the roadway type suffix shall be written out on the plat and not abbreviated b final plat for major subdivision proposed roadway names are required to be shown on the final plat and will become the official names once the plat has been recorded with the dane county register of deeds an addressing plan shall be submitted along with the final plat as required in n of the city subdivision the addressing plan has been approved the authorities and plan preparer will sign off on the plan since the towns and the county are responsible for addressing in the etj area an addressing plan is not required to be submitted with an etj plat c certified survey map any roadways created by a csm shall be named in accordance with the roadway naming standards new addresses will be assigned to newly created lots and outlots on a certified survey map by the property addressing authority d planned development district general development plan pddgdp any private roadways approved planned development district general development plan shall include roadway names an addressing plan shall be submitted along with the precise implementation plan pip e annexation when an area is annexed into the city and has a roadway with an existing name the city roadway naming authority may rename the roadway to comply with the roadway naming standards the property addressing authority shall assign addresses to all existing parcels within the annexation area including properties with preexisting addresses f private roadway name changes owners of private roadways may initiate a formal name change in writing private roadway names may not be changed without written approval by the citys roadway naming authority and the public works committee g property address corrections 1 when the property addressing authority determines that an address is not in compliance with the citys standards and it is in the public interest to change an address for the efficient delivery of emergency and other services the city property addressing authority shall change the address the property addressing authority shall provide written notification to the property owner at least thirty 30 days prior to the effective date of the change 2 when a parcel is annexed by the city the parcel shall be assigned new official property addresses consistent with the property addressing standards of the city 3 when properties are redeveloped new addresses shall be assigned  part   roadway naming standards if a proposed roadway is not an extension of an existing roadway the new roadway names shall be assigned in accordance with the following standards names should be pleasant sounding appropriate easy to read and pronounce especially in an emergency situation and should add to the pride of the community a selection of roadway names 1 roadway name length roadway names shall have no fewer than three and no more than fourteen 14 characters if the roadway will cross a baseline thereby requiring a directional prefix then the roadway name shall be limited to twelve 12 characters a space between two words is considered a character 2 duplication of existing roadway names to eliminate potential confusion and delay of emergency response duplication of roadway names shall not be permitted roadways with the same name but different suffix designations shall be considered duplicate roadway names eg smith drive and smith lane are duplicates culdesacs that terminate a that have the same name at the roadway but will have the court suffix are the only exceptions as described in e1 3 similar or confusing spelling to eliminate confusion names that are difficult to spell have similar spelling can be spelled several different ways or have phonetically confusing spelling will not be approved eg stonehenge vs stonehedge  similar spelling and broome vs broom  spelled two ways 4 unconventional spelling to avoid confusion and allow for accurate verbal communication in emergency situations unconventional spelling of words in roadway names shall be prohibited eg wynd chime golde bar 5 multiple pronunciations roadway names that may be pronounced in a number of different ways will not be approved 6 similar sounding roadway names which are different but sound similar will not be approved eg broom and bloom 7 emergency confusion roadway names that could cause confusion in emergency situations will not be approved eg fire lane station street 8 offensive roadways names that may be offensive slang double meanings etc will not be approved 9 frivolous roadway names that are considered frivolous or complicated or have unconventional spellings will not be approved eg i did it my way 10 vanity names roadway names that identify with a specific company or private entity will not be approved for public roadways but may be approved for private roadways 11 numbers and alphabet numerical names 1st second etc or alphabet letter names a street b drive will not be approved 12 use of roadway type suffix or directional prefix words roadway names that include the directional prefix or the roadway type suffix or similar words as the roadway name or in the roadway name will not be approved eg west avenue and melrose place drive 13 abbreviations roadway names may not contain abbreviations for example saint must be written out in full 14 use of oldolde or new roadway names that contain the separate words old olde or new will not be approved eg new castle olde english 15 punctuation punctuation is not allowed in roadway names names shall not contain hyphens apostrophes or other nonletter characters 16 capitalization upper and lower case characters may not be designated in roadway names 17 multiword roadway names roadway names shall be comprised of no more than two words a roadway name may only contain one space if it is a multiword name 18 other unacceptable roadway names roadway names deemed unacceptable by the city roadway naming authority are also prohibited b directional prefix designations directional prefixes shall only be north south east or west when a roadway crosses either baseline the appropriate directional prefix shall be assigned directional prefixes shall not be abbreviated on recorded documents such as plats and certified survey maps bristol street is the eastwest baseline and main street is the northsouth baseline c suffix roadway type designations every roadway name shall be assigned a roadway type suffix suffixes shall be spelled out and not abbreviated when submitted to the roadway naming authority the following table includes a list of allowable suffixes no other suffixes may be used in addition the following table includes a description of the appropriate usage of each roadway type suffix allowable suffixes for private roadways shall be limited to alley circle court lane place square and trail acceptable suffix description of appropriate usage abbreviation alley service road providing secondary access to adjoining properties alley avenue continuous roadway not limited to a single subdivision avenues may be constructed with or without a landscaped median ave boulevard a continuous roadway divided by a landscaped median and spans more than one subdivision blvd circle a circle is a short roadway that begins and loops back to terminate on the same roadway circles may not contain outlets or other circles cir court a permanent culdesac ending in a turnaround ct drive a curving continuous longer than 1000 feet that spans more than one subdivision dr highway designated state federal or county maintained roadways with lettered or numbered names hwy lane local roadway within a single subdivision ln parkway a continuous roadway with a median reflecting the parkway character implied by the name pky place short roadway within a single subdivision typically no longer than a block in length pl road a designated roadway predominantly outside the corporate limits rd square a square is a short roadway that begins and terminates on two separate roadways it has no developable lots enclosed on the inside of square sq street a roadway that may or may not span more than one subdivision st trail local roadway within a single subdivision trl way a continuous curvilinear roadway may or may not span more than one subdivision way d reservation of roadway names the reservation of roadway names is prohibited e naming and roadway configuration 1 culdesacs a culdesac originating fromon a shall be given a different name than the a culdesac that terminates a must bear the same name as the it terminates but it shall have the court suffix in this case it would not be considered a duplicate name per a2 2 roadway direction changes a roadway that changes direction one or more times shall retain the same name over the entire length within the city corporate limits 3 naming discontinuous roadways that will be aligned and may be potentially joined in the future if an existing roadway in one subdivision has a temporary end at the property or subdivision boundary line and is on the same alignment as a new roadway in another subdivision but they do not connect the new roadway should bear the same name if future development expects to connect the two 4 limitation on two roadways intersecting each other two roadways may not intersect more than once with the exception of a circle and another roadway 5 naming when extending an existing roadway a new roadway that will be an extension of an existing roadway must be given the same name as the existing roadway a directional prefix must be assigned if the roadway is extended to cross a base line f naming private roadways all private roadways shall be named private roadways are subject to this naming standard just as public roadways are g roadway signage 1 names for public and private roadways shall be posted in accordance with standards established by the city signs shall include the directional prefix if applicable roadway name and roadway type suffix 2 all roadways that cross a city limit boundary shall be signed entering rural addressing system and entering municipal addressing system at the city limit  4152014   part   property addressing standards a addresses shall be assigned to all lots in a subdivision including outlots all properties within the city must have an address b property addressing authority the property addressing authority shall be the building inspection department c developer responsibility developers subdividers preparing subdivision plats shall provide an addressing plan for the proposed plat in accordance with all applicable standards the addresses shall be depicted on an exhibit with all final plat submissions an approval signature by the property addressing authority is required prior to final plat approval refer to n1 of the subdivision property address numbering grid the city shall maintain a property address numbering grid for addresses addresses shall be assigned to parcels based on the location of the proper door e point of origin the center of the grid shall be the intersection of bristol and main streets with all blocks adjacent to these roadways having a designation of 100 numbers shall increase northward and southward from main street and eastward and westward from bristol street f evenodd numbers the north side of eastwest roadways and the west side of northsouth roadways shall be assigned even numbers the south side of eastwest roadways and the east side of northsouth roadways shall be assigned odd numbers g number block addresses should be assigned at a rate of 400 per mile the lowest address on the odd side of the roadway shall end in 1 the lowest address on the even side of the roadway shall end in 2 for example 501 and 502 for the 500 block of west main street h corner lots shall initially be assigned an address on both roadways ultimately the official addresses should be assigned based on the location of the proper door i roadways change direction roadways that change direction should be addressed according to the prevailing roadway direction the prevailing direction is based on the longest segment in the event of a tie in length of two or more segments in different directions the city property addressing authority will make a decision j diagonal roadways a roadway oriented on a diagonal shall be designated as an eastwest or northsouth roadway for addressing purposes the designation shall be made based on the eastwest distance versus northsouth distance whichever is greater diagonal roadways shall be addressed throughout the length in a consistent manner k curvilinear roadways curvilinear roadways shall maintain either an eastwest or northsouth address scheme curvilinear roadways shall not change directional schemes without changing roadway names l private roadways residential properties on private roadways shall be assigned addresses based on the private roadway name and not based off of the public roadway adjacent to the development m displaying addresses refer to n duplication addresses may not be duplicated on a roadway for example if 110 n walker way is previously assigned then 110 s walker way would not be acceptable but 112 s walker way would be allowed if there is no 112 n walker way o multifamily buildings units within multifamily buildings that have an external proper door that accesses only that unit shall be assigned a separate property address number units with a common proper door shall be assigned unit numbers and the building containing those units shall be assigned a numeric property address in buildings that have both individual and shared proper doors the building shall be assigned one address and the units assigned a unit number individual units requiring unit designations should be assigned numbers rather than letters p fractional addresses fractional addresses shall not be used for example 1020 12 is not allowed but 1020 jones street #2 is correct q alleys properties adjacent to alleys must be addressed from nonalley roadways  part   building numbering and displaying standards a the proper location of building address numbers is an important aspect of quickly locating a home or structure in emergency situations the standards contained herein shall be followed to ensure address numbers are properly located and displayed 1 property address numbers shall be conspicuously placed on the exterior faade of the closest wall to the street corresponding with the buildings address 2 the numbers shall be placed in one of the following locations immediately above or at the side of the proper door immediately above the garage door at the side of the garage door closest to the proper door or when the closest wall to the street does not contain either the proper door or a garage door at the location on the wall closest to the proper door 3 the architecture of the building will determine proper placement which shall be subject to final approval by the building inspection division 4 numbers shall be placed a minimum of five feet above the surface below them 5 numbers shall be placed no higher than the eave line of a singlestory building nor higher than the top of the first story of the building on a multistory structure 6 numbers shall be located to be plainly visible from the street and maintained such that they are not obscured by parked vehicles or landscaping features on the property 7 additional address numbers may be displayed in a secondary location b whenever any building is situated more than seventyfive 75 feet from the road rightofway the number of such building shall be conspicuously displayed at the front of the property and should be located near the walk or driveway or upon a gate post fence post or other appropriate place so as to be easily discernible from the roadway numbers shall be placed not less than three feet above nor more than ten 10 feet above the surface of the ground immediately below the location of the number numbers shall be placed and the property maintained such that they shall not be obscured by piled snow trees landscaping shrubbery or other structure or landscaping feature on the building or property c properties fronting andor addressed on a private roadway shall have range of address numbers displayed on property at every intersection with a public roadway display sign shall be sixteen 16 inches square and in colors used on public roadway signs private roadways and alleys shall also be signed to public roadway standards d properties that have an alley as an access for vehicles to the property andor structure shall have the address displayed on the alley access similar to the proper or overhead garage door standards when facing a roadway e numbers for residential structures one to four units shall not be less than three inches in height nor less than two inches in width numbers shall have a contrasting background f numbers for residential structures greater than four units and all commercialindustrial structures shall be not less than six inches in height or less than three inches in width numbers shall have a contrasting background g private roadways shall also be signed with a sixteen 16 inches by twentyfour 24 inches sign stating private drive and no thru traffic the private roadway shall also have the standard twelve 12 inches by eighteen 18 inches fire lane sign when required this sign shall be located on private property directly adjacent to the rightofway the lowest portion of the signage shall be a minimum of five feet above grade fire lane sign shall be the highest sign where required h multifamily commercial and industrial structures that do not have the proper doors facing the roadway to which the structure is addressed shall display the addresses on the wall facade that is parallel with or facing the roadway  11182014   part   violations and penalties a any person who violates a provision of this chapter shall be subject to a general forfeiture as provided in general penalties b each day the violation exists or continues to exist shall constitute a separate offense c in addition to any other penalty imposed by this chapter for a violation the city reserves and maintains a continued right to abate violations of this chapter in the event the city seeks injunctive relief to abate the violation the person who is found to have violated this chapter shall upon conviction thereof be subject to the penalties set forth in shall pay all costs and expenses including actual and reasonable attorney and other fees involved in the enforcement action  part residential property maintenance code finding and legislative purpose a 1 the common council finds that there are now or may be in the future real property and buildings in the city which are so dilapidated unsightly dangerous unsanitary overcrowded or inadequately maintained as to constitute a menace to the persons residing on such property 2 it is the purpose of this chapter to preserve and promote the public health safety and general wellbeing of the people of the city by regulating in a manner which corrects the above problems with only minimal infringement of each affected persons property b applicability this chapter shall apply to all residential land and buildings c title this chapter shall be known and may be cited as the property maintenance code of the city hereinafter referred to as this chapter    general requirements relating to the safe and sanitary maintenance of parts of dwelling units and accessory structures every owner or occupant if the occupant has assumed responsibility under the terms of a written lease shall either personally or by agent improve and maintain all property under his or her control to comply with the following requirements a every premise shall be maintained in a clean sanitary and safe condition and complies with all applicable legal requirements of the city b every foundation roof floor exterior and interior wall ceiling inside and outside stair every porch and every appurtenance thereto shall be safe to use and capable of supporting the loads that normal use may cause to be placed thereon  and shall be maintained in sound condition and good repair c all exterior surfaces of buildings and fences made of materials not inherently resistant to deterioration shall be periodically coated with paint or another suitable preservation which provides adequate resistance to weathering d if gutters leaders and downspouts are provided they shall be maintained in good working condition as to provide proper drainage of stormwater this shall include being substantially free from rust andor corrosion e 1 every window exterior door and hatchway or similar device shall be so constructed to exclude insects during that portion of the year when there is a need for protection against mosquitoes flies and other flying insects 2 every doorway used for ventilation and opening directly from a dwelling unit to outside space shall have supplied properly fitting screens 3 every window or other device with openings to outdoor space used for ventilation shall be supplied with screens f accessory structures present or provided by the owner agent or tenant occupant on the premises of a dwelling shall be structurally sound and be maintained in good repair g all vacant lots shall be maintained by the owner in a clean sanitary and safe condition no debris shall be allowed to accumulate on such vacant lot and it shall be maintained in ratfree condition    responsibilities of owners and occupants every owner or occupant if the occupant has assumed responsibility under the terms of a written lease shall either personally or by agent improve and maintain all property under his or her control to comply with the following requirements a except where the occupant has agreed to do such service the owner shall hang and maintain all screens screen doors storm windows and storm doors required by this chapter  b every owner or occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall provide and maintain the dwelling or dwelling unit free from hazards to health  c every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall store and dispose of all his or her rubbish garbage and refuse in full compliance with the citys solid waste managementrefuse collection ordinance  d every owner of a dwelling containing three or more dwelling units shall supply facilities or refuse containers for the sanitary and safe storage andor disposal of rubbish and garbage in the case of single or two family dwellings it shall be the responsibility of each occupant to furnish such facilities or refuse containers  e 1 every dwelling multiple dwelling or accessory structure and the premises on which located shall be maintained in a ratfree and ratproof environment 2 materials stored outside the dwelling shall be stacked in an orderly fashion 3 any materials acceptable to the county health department may be used for ratproofing  f no owner of a dwelling containing three or more dwelling units shall accumulate or permit the accumulation of rubbish boxes lumber scrap metal or any other materials in such a manner that may provide a rat harborage in or about the shared or public areas of a dwelling or its premises  g except as provided by subsection h when an occupants unit is infested with insects andor rodents he or she shall be responsible for the cost of their extermination so long as the property owner has provided monthly professional pest control service in the common areas of the building and so long as the owner has informed the occupant in writing of the responsibility for such costs the property owner shall arrange extermination services with a wisconsin certified pest control technician and may charge the occupant at the property owners actual cost h if an infestation has moved into adjacent units in the building the cost of the extermination shall be the responsibility of the tenant that caused the infestation unless it is determined that the property owner has failed to maintain the common areas of the building in a reasonably clean safe and sanitary condition or if the point of origin of the infestation cannot be determined in such cases the owner shall bear the cost of the extermination the determination as to the origin of the infestation will be made by the director of building inspection in conjunction with a wisconsin certified pest control technician used by the property owner for monthly pest control services in the building the property owner shall keep a written record of pest control programs and treatments of each building with more than two units of living accommodations that have common areas rowhouses and condo units that are rented shall also be subject to these provisions regarding extermination even if there is no common area involved further the property owner shall include language in each lease agreement informing the tenantlessee of their responsibilities in these matters i all dwelling units that share a common wall shall have the same responsibilities regarding extermination of infestations of insects or rodents listed in subsections g and h this includes duplex units rowhouse units and condo units regardless of owner occupancy  652012  prior code  1563   minimum thermal standards the owner of any dwelling unit shall provide heating equipment and apparatuses which are properly installed in accordance with the building code and maintained in a safe and good working condition    minimum standards for basic equipment and facilities a no person shall occupy as owner occupant or let to another for occupancy a dwelling or dwelling unit for the purposes of living sleeping bathing cooking or eating therein which does not comply with the building code b cooking facilities shall not be applicable to rooming houses in reference to rented rooms    maximum density a dwelling unit shall not be occupied by more than one family family shall mean an individual or two or more persons each related by blood marriage adoption or legal guardianship for purposes of this code a group of not more than four persons not necessarily related by blood or marriage living together in a single living unit will be considered equivalent to a single family    minimum standards for light and ventilation no person shall occupy as owner occupant or let to another for occupancy any dwelling unit for the purpose of living therein which does not comply with the requirements of this section a every habitable room shall conform with city codes as to light standards according to building codes at the time of construction b every habitable room shall conform to city codes as to ventilation standards according to building codes at the time of construction c every dwelling or dwelling unit shall contain safe electrical wiring and fixtures d every public hall and stairway in every multiple dwelling shall be adequately lighted by material or artificial light at all times in accordance with building code    inspections the building inspector is authorized to cause such exterior inspections as are deemed necessary without giving notice to the property owner provided that the inspection can be conducted from a location not on the owners property or  the building inspector has probable cause to initiate an inspection due to potential property maintenance code violations that could endanger the public health safety andor welfare if it becomes necessary to perform an inspection which requires the building inspector to go on the owners property the building inspector shall provide a minimum of five calendar days notice to the owner or agent prior to conducting the inspection such notice shall be sent in writing to the owner and shall state the alleged violations the five calendar day notice requirement shall not apply when the building inspector has probable cause to believe that a violation exists which if not corrected immediately could be life threatening andor result in serious sickness or injury  1999  prior code  1568   notice of violation a whenever the building inspector determines that any dwelling unit or the premises surrounding them fails to meet the requirements set forth in this chapter or in applicable rules and regulations issued pursuant thereto the building inspector in accordance with existing legislation shall issue a notice setting forth the alleged failures and advising the owner occupant operator or agent that such failures must be corrected this notice shall 1 be in writing  2 set forth the alleged violation of the ordinance codified in this chapter or of applicable rules and regulations issued pursuant thereto  3 describe the dwelling or dwelling unit where the violations are alleged to exist or to have been committed  4 specify a specific date for the correction of the violation the date of correction shall be at the discretion of the building inspector based on the circumstances of each violation however in nonlife threatening situations a minimum of thirty 30 days shall be allowed to correct the violation no violation shall be permitted to exist beyond a maximum of one hundred and twenty 120 days without the approval of the property maintenance board of appeals as provided in   5 be served upon the owner occupant operator or agent of the dwelling or dwelling unit personally or by registered mail return receipt requested addressed to the owner occupant operator or agent if one or more persons to whom such notice is addressed cannot be found after diligent effort to do so service may be made upon such persons by posting the notice in or about the dwelling or dwelling unit described in the notice or by
